Keywords: Monte Carlo Optimization, Black-box Optimization, Parametric Learning, Automated Annealing, Bias-variance-covariance

Parametric Learning and Monte Carlo Optimization

\nameDavid H. Wolpert \emaildhw@email.arc.nasa.gov
\addrMS 269-1, Ames Research Center
Moffett Field, CA 94035. \AND\nameDev G. Rajnayaran \emaildgorur@stanford.edu
\addrDepartment of Aeronautics and Astronautics,
Durand Rm. 158, 496 Lomita Mall, Stanford, CA 94305
Abstract

This paper uncovers and explores the close relationship between Monte Carlo Optimization of a parametrized integral (MCO), Parametric machine-Learning (PL), and ‚Äòblackbox‚Äô or ‚Äòoracle‚Äô-based optimization (BO). We make four contributions. First, we prove that MCO is mathematically identical to a broad class of PL problems. This identity potentially provides a new application domain for all broadly applicable PL techniques: MCO. Second, we introduce immediate sampling, a new version of the Probability Collectives (PC) algorithm for blackbox optimization. Immediate sampling transforms the original BO problem into an MCO problem. Accordingly, by combining these first two contributions, we can apply all PL techniques to BO. In our third contribution we validate this way of improving BO by demonstrating that cross-validation and bagging improve immediate sampling. Finally, conventional MC and MCO procedures ignore the relationship between the sample point locations and the associated values of the integrand; only the values of the integrand at those locations are considered. We demonstrate that one can exploit the sample location information using PL techniques, for example by forming a fit of the sample locations to the associated values of the integrand. This provides an additional way to apply PL techniques to improve MCO.

1 Introduction

This paper uncovers and explores some aspects of the close relationship between Monte Carlo Optimization of a parametrized integral (MCO), Parametric machine Learning (PL), and ‚Äòblackbox‚Äô or ‚Äòoracle-based‚Äô optimization (BO). We make four primary contributions. First, we establish a mathematical identity equating MCO with PL. This identity potentially provides a new application domain for all broadly-applicable PL techniques, viz., MCO.

Our second contribution is the introduction of immediate sampling. This is a new version of the Probability Collectives (PC) approach to blackbox optimization. PC encompasses Estimation of Distribution Algorithms (EDAs)(De¬†Bonet et¬†al., 1997; Larraaga and Lozano, 2001; Lozano et¬†al., 2005) and the Cross Entropy (CE) method¬†(Rubinstein and Kroese, 2004) as special cases. However PC is broader and more fully motivated. This means it uncovers (and overcomes) formal shortcomings in those other approaches.

In the immediate sampling version of PC the original BO problem is transformed into an MCO problem. In light of our first contribution, this means we can apply PL to immediate sampling. In this way a‚Äãl‚Äãlùëéùëôùëôall PL techniques ‚Äî including cross-validation, bagging, boosting, active learning, stacking, and others ‚Äî can be applied to blackbox optimization.

In our third contribution we experimentally explore the power of this identity between MCO and PL. In these experiments we demonstrate that cross-validation and bagging improve the performance of immediate sampling blackbox optimization. In particular, in these experiments we show that cross-validation can be used to adaptively set an ‚Äòannealing schedule‚Äô for blackbox optimization using immediate sampling without any extra calls to the oracle. In some cases, we show that this adaptively formed annealing schedule results in better optimization performance than any exponential annealing schedule.111Since they are special cases of PC, presumably we could similarly apply PL techniques to improve EDA‚Äôs or the CE method.

Finally, conventional MC and MCO procedures ignore the relationship between the sample point locations and the associated values of the integrand. (Only the values of the integrand at the sample locations are considered by such algorithms.) We end by exploring ways to use PL techniques to exploit the information in the sample locations, for instance, by Bayesian fitting of a surface from the sample locations to the associated values of the integrand. This constitutes yet another way of applying PL to MCO in general, and therefore to BO in particular.

1.1 Background on PL, MCO, Blackbox Optimization, and PC

We begin by sketching the four disciplines discussed in this paper:

  1. 1.

    A large number of parametric machine-learning problems share the following two properties. First, the goal in these problems is to find a set of parameters, Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, that minimizes an integral of a function that is parametrized by Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. Second, to help us find that Œ∏ùúÉ\theta we are are given samples of the integrand. These problems reduce to a sample-based search for the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta that we predict minimizes the integral. We will refer to problems of this class as Parametric Learning (PL) problems.

    An example of PL is parametric supervised learning, where we want to find an optimal predictor or regressor zŒ∏subscriptùëßùúÉz_{\theta} that minimizes the associated expected loss, ‚à´ùëëx‚Äãùëëy‚ÄãP‚Äã(x)‚ÄãP‚Äã(y‚à£x)‚ÄãL‚Äã[y,zŒ∏‚Äã(x)]differential-dùë•differential-dùë¶ùëÉùë•ùëÉconditionalùë¶ùë•ùêøùë¶subscriptùëßùúÉùë•\int dx\,dy\;P(x)P(y\mid x)L[y,z_{\theta}(x)], where xùë•x‚Äôs are inputs and yùë¶y‚Äôs are outputs. We do not, however, know P‚Äã(x)‚ÄãP‚Äã(y‚à£x)ùëÉùë•ùëÉconditionalùë¶ùë•P(x)P(y\mid x). Instead, we are provided a training set of samples of P‚Äã(x)‚ÄãP‚Äã(y‚à£x)ùëÉùë•ùëÉconditionalùë¶ùë•P(x)P(y\mid x). The associated PL problem is to use those samples to estimate the optimal Œ∏ùúÉ\theta.

  2. 2.

    MCO is a technique for solving problems of the form argmin‚à´œïùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)subscriptitalic-œïdifferential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï{}_{\phi}\int dw\;U(w,\phi)¬†(see Ermoliev and Norkin, 1998). MCO starts by replacing that integral with an importance-sample generated estimate of it. That estimate is a sum parametrized by œïitalic-œï\phi. In MCO one searches for the value œïitalic-œï\phi that minimizes this sum; the result of this search is one‚Äôs estimate of the œïitalic-œï\phi that optimizes the original integral.

  3. 3.

    Blackbox optimization algorithms are ways to minimize functions of the form G:X‚Üí‚Ñù:ùê∫‚Üíùëã‚ÑùG:X\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}} when one does not actually know the function Gùê∫G. Such algorithms work by an iterative process in which they first select a query x‚ààXùë•ùëãx\in X, and then an ‚Äòoracle‚Äô returns to the algorithm a (potentially noise-corrupted) value G‚Äã(x)ùê∫ùë•G(x), and no other information, in particular, no gradient information. The difference between one blackbox optimization algorithm and another is how they select each successive query based on the earlier responses of the oracle. Examples of blackbox optimization algorithms are genetic algorithms¬†(Mitchell, 1996), simulated annealing¬†(Kirkpatrick et¬†al., 1983), hill-climbing algorithms, Response-Surface Methods (RSMs)¬†(Myers and Montgomery, 2002), and some forms of Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP)¬†(Gill et¬†al., 1981; Nocedal and Wright, 1999), Estimation of Distribution Algorithms (EDAs)(De¬†Bonet et¬†al., 1997; Larraaga and Lozano, 2001; Lozano et¬†al., 2005), tabu search, the Cross Entropy (CE) method¬†(Rubinstein and Kroese, 2004), and others.

  4. 4.

    PC is a set of techniques that can be used for blackbox optimization. Broadly speaking, PC works by transforming a search for the best value of a variable xùë•x into a search for the best probability distribution over the variable, q‚Äã(x)ùëûùë•q(x)¬†(see Wolpert et¬†al., 2006; Macready and Wolpert, 2005; Wolpert, 2003, 2004a; Bieniawski and Wolpert, 2004; Antoine et¬†al., 2004; Lee and Wolpert, 2004). Once one solves for the optimal q‚Äã(x)ùëûùë•q(x), inversion to get the optimal xùë•x for the original search problem is stochastic; one simply samples qùëûq. As described below, PC has many practical strengths, and is related to RSMs, EDAs, and the CE method.

1.2 Roadmap of This Paper

We make four primary contributions:

  1. 1.

    Sec.¬†2 begins with a detailed review of MCO and PL. Conventional analysis of Monte Carlo estimation involves a bias-variance decomposition of the error of the estimator of a particular integral. We show that for MCO, a full analysis requires more than simply extending such bias-variance analysis separately to each of the estimators given by the separate œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs. Moments coupling the errors of the estimators for the separate œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs must also be taken into account. How should we do that?

    To answer this, we note that in a different context, the techniques of PL take such coupling moments into account, albeit implicitly. This leads us to explore the relation between MCO and PL. This in turn leads to our first major contribution, the proof that MCO is identical to PL. This contribution means that one can apply all PL techniques, for instance, cross-validation, bagging, boosting, stacking, active learning and others, to MCO. Such PL-based MCO (PLMCO) provides a new way of minimizing potentially high-dimensional parametrized integrals.

    Experimentally testing the utility of applying PL to MCO requires an MCO application domain. Here we choose the domain of blackbox optimization. To establish how blackbox optimization is an application domain for MCO requires our second contribution, as follows.

  2. 2.

    We start in Sec.¬†3 by presenting an overview of previous versions of the blackbox optimization approach of PC. We then make our second contribution in the following section, where we introduce immediate sampling, a new version of PC that overcomes some of the limitations of previous versions.

    These first two contributions are combined by the fact that immediate sampling is a special case of MCO. The resultant identity between PL and immediate sampling means that, in principle, any PL technique can be applied to blackbox optimization. In particular, regularization, cross-validation, bagging, active learning, boosting, stacking, kernel machines, and others, can be ‚Äòcut and paste‚Äô to do blackbox optimization. This use of PL for blackbox optimization constitutes a new application domain for PL.

    In Sec.¬†4.5 we present some concrete instances of how to modify immediate sampling to use PLMCO rather than conventional MCO. It is important to note that when applied (via immediate sampling) to blackbox optimization, these PL techniques do n‚Äão‚Äãtùëõùëúùë°not require additional calls to the oracle. For example, using cross-validation to set regularization parameters in immediate sampling (the equivalent of an annealing schedule in SA) does not involve running the entire blackbox optimization algorithm with different regularization schedules. As another example, using bagging in immediate sampling does not mean running the optimization algorithm multiple times based on different subsets of the sample points found so far.

  3. 3.

    Our third contribution is to experimentally demonstrate in Sec.¬†5 that PLMCO substantially outperforms conventional MCO when used this way for blackbox optimization. We are particularly interested in blackbox optimization problems where calls to the oracle are the primary expense. Accordingly, non-oracle, ‚Äòoffline‚Äô computation is considered free. So in our experiments we compare algorithms based on the values of Gùê∫G found by the algorithms versus the associated number of calls to the oracle222See ¬†Wolpert and Macready (1997); Droste et¬†al. (2002); Wolpert and Macready (2005); Corne and Knowles (2003); Igel and Toussaint (2004); Schumacher et¬†al. (2001) for a discussion of the mathematics relating algorithms under such performance measures.. In particular, we show that bagging and cross-validation leads to faster blackbox optimization on two well-known benchmark problems for continuous nonconvex optimization.

    It should be emphasized that these experiments are not intended to investigate whether PLMCO applied to immediate sampling is superior to other blackbox optimization algorithms. Rather their purpose is to investigate whether one can indeed leverage the formal connection between PL and MCO to improve immediate sampling. Accordingly, these experiments are on toy domains, and we do not compare performance with other blackbox optimization algorithms. We leave such comparisons to future papers.

  4. 4.

    In estimating the value of an integral based on random samples of its integrand, conventional MC and MCO techniques ignore how the locations of the sample points are related to the associated values of the integrand. Such techniques concentrate exclusively on those sample values of the integrand that are returned by the oracle. However, one can use the sample locations and associated integrand values to form a supervised learning fit to the integrand. In principle, such a fit can then be used to improve the overall estimate of the integral.

    In ‚Äòfit-based‚Äô MC and MCO one uses all the data at hand to fit the integrand and then uses that fit to improve the algorithm. In this paper, we concentrate on situations where the data at hand consist only of sample locations and the associated values of the integrand, but in other situations the data at hand may also include information like the gradient of the integrand at the sample points. In their most general form, fit-based MC and MCO include techniques to exploit such information.

    One natural Bayesian approach to fit-based MC uses Gaussian processes. Work adopting this approach, for the case where the data only contain sample locations and associated integrand values, is reviewed in ¬†Rasmussen and Gharamani (2003). In Sec.¬†6 we generalize that work on fit-based MC, e.g., to allow non-Bayesian approaches. In that section, we also consider fit-based MCO in general, and fit-based immediate sampling in particular.

One of the ways cross-validation is used in these experiments is to set a regularization parameter. In immediate sampling, the regularization parameter plays the same role as the temperature does in simulated annealing. So intuitively speaking, our results show how to use cross-validation to set an annealing schedule adaptively for blackbox optimization, without extra calls to the oracle. We show in particular that such auto-annealing outperforms the best-fit exponential annealing schedule.

There are more topics involving the connection between MCO, immediate sampling and PL, than can be explored in this single paper. One such topic is how to incorporate constraints on xùë•x in immediate sampling. Another important topic involves a derivation from first principles of the objective function used in immediate sampling. These two topics are briefly discussed in the appendices. Some other topics are mentioned, albeit even more briefly, in the conclusion.

1.3 Notation

As a point of notation, we will use the term ‚Äòdistribution‚Äô to refer either to a probability distribution or a density function, with the associated Borel field implicitly fixing the meaning. Similarly, we will write integrals even when we mean sums; the measure of the integral is implicitly taken to be the one appropriate for the the argument. We will use ŒòŒò\Theta to indicate the Heaviside or indicator function, which is 1 if its argument is positive, and 0 otherwise.

We will use ùí´ùí´\mathscr{P} to mean the set of all distributions over XùëãX. We are primarily interested in XùëãX‚Äôs that are too large to permit computations involving all members of ùí´ùí´\mathscr{P}. Accordingly, we will will work with parametrized subsets ùí¨‚äÇùí´ùí¨ùí´{\mathscr{Q}}\subset{\mathscr{P}}. We generically write that (possibly vector-valued)parameter as Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, and write the element of ùí¨ùí¨\mathscr{Q} specified by Œ∏ùúÉ\theta as qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}. We use ùîºùîº\mathbb{E} to indicate the expectation of a random variable. Subscripts on ùîºùîº\mathbb{E} are sometimes used to indicate the distribution(s) defining the expectation.

We take any oracle ùí¢ùí¢{\mathscr{G}} to be an xùë•x-indexed set of independent stochastic processes, and use the symbol gùëîg to indicate the generic output of the oracle in response to any query. With some abuse of notation, we denote the output of the oracle for query xùë•x as P‚Äã(g‚à£x,ùí¢)ùëÉconditionalùëîùë•ùí¢P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}). For a noise-free, or single-valued oracle, we write P‚Äã(g‚à£x,ùí¢)=Œ¥‚Äã(g‚àíG‚Äã(x))ùëÉconditionalùëîùë•ùí¢ùõøùëîùê∫ùë•P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}})=\delta(g-G(x)) for some function Gùê∫G implicitly specified by ùí¢ùí¢\mathscr{G}, where Œ¥(.)\delta(.) is the Dirac delta function.

When there is both a factual version of a random variable and a posterior distribution over counter-factual values of that variable, they must be distinguished. In general this requires extending the conventional Bayesian formalism¬†(see Wolpert, 1997, 1996). Here, though, it suffices for us to indicate counter-factual values by a subscript cùëêc. Say there is a factual oracle ùí¢ùí¢\mathscr{G}, and we are provided a data set Dùê∑D formed by sampling ùí¢ùí¢\mathscr{G}. We use superscripts to denote different samples in that data set. Then Dùê∑D in turn induces a posterior over oracles, and we write that posterior as P‚Äã(ùí¢c‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùí¢ùëêùê∑P({\mathscr{G}}_{c}\mid D).

2 MCO and PL

In this section we review PL and MCO show that they are mathematically identical.

2.1 Overview of PL

A broad class of parametric machine learning problems try to find

2.2 Overview of MCO

Consider the problem

(P2)::P2absent\displaystyle\mathrm{(P2):} argminœï‚ààŒ¶‚Äã‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï).subscriptargminitalic-œïŒ¶differential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{\phi\in\Phi}\int dw\;U(w,\phi).

for some sampling distribution vùë£{v}. Following the usual importance sampling procedure, we IID sample vùë£{v} to form a sample set {U(wi,.):i=1,‚Ä¶NU(w^{i},.):i=1,\ldots N}, which specifies a set of NùëÅN sample functions

It is implicitly assumed that for any wùë§w, we can evaluate v‚Äã(w)ùë£ùë§v(w) up to an overall normalization constant.

In MCO, these NùëÅN functions are used in combination with any prior information to estimate the solution to (P2). Conventionally, this is done by approximating the solution to (P2) with the solution to the problem

(P3)::P3absent\displaystyle\mathrm{(P3):} argminœï‚Äã‚àëiri‚Äã(œï).subscriptargminitalic-œïsubscriptùëñsuperscriptùëüùëñitalic-œï\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{\phi}\sum_{i}r^{i}(\phi).

We define

For notational simplicity, the subscripts will usually be omitted in these expressions. We will use the term naive MCO to refer to solving (P3) by minimizing ‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï)^‚Ñíitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi).

2.3 Statistical Analysis of MCO

The statistical analysis of MC estimation of integrals is a relatively mature field¬†(see Robert and Casella, 2004; Fishman, 1996). We now show that when such MC estimation is combined with parameter optimization in MCO, the analysis becomes much more involved.

2.3.1 Review: MC Estimation

First consider MC estimation, with no mention of MCO. We first need to to specify a loss function L(.,.)L(.,.) that will couple our mathematics with real-world costs. The first argument of such an LùêøL is the output of the estimation algorithm under consideration. The second argument is the quantity statistically sampled by that algorithm. The associated value of LùêøL is the cost if the algorithm produces the output specified in that first argument, using the quantity specified in the second argument.

As an example, consider importance-sampled MC estimation of an integral. Using the MCO notation just introduced, we use ‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï)^‚Ñíitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) as an estimate of ‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)‚Ñíitalic-œï{\mathscr{L}}(\phi) for some fixed œïitalic-œï\phi. The quantity being sampled is the function U(.,œï)U(.,\phi), and the output of the algorithm is ‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï)^‚Ñíitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi). Accordingly, these are the arguments of the loss function.

The most popular loss function in statistical analysis of MC integral estimation is quadratic loss, given below.

L(‚Ñí^(œï),U(.,œï))\displaystyle L({\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi),U(.,\phi)) ‚âú‚âú\displaystyle\triangleq [‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï)‚àí‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)]2.superscriptdelimited-[]^‚Ñíitalic-œïdifferential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï2\displaystyle[{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)-\int dw\;U(w,\phi)]^{2}.

Unless explicitly stated otherwise, we will henceforth use the term ‚Äòexpected loss‚Äô to refer to the average of this loss function over sample sets. Since ‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï)^‚Ñíitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is an unbiased estimate of ‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)‚Ñíitalic-œï{\mathscr{L}}(\phi), the expected loss is the sample variance,

Var‚Äã(‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï))Var^‚Ñíitalic-œï\displaystyle{\mbox{Var}}({\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)) =\displaystyle= ùîº‚Äã([‚àëj=1NU‚Äã(wj,œï)N‚Äãv‚Äã(wj)]2)‚àí[ùîº‚Äã(‚àëj=1NU‚Äã(wj,œï)N‚Äãv‚Äã(wj))]2ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëóitalic-œïùëÅùë£superscriptùë§ùëó2superscriptdelimited-[]ùîºsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëóitalic-œïùëÅùë£superscriptùë§ùëó2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}([\sum_{j=1}^{N}\frac{U(w^{j},\phi)}{Nv(w^{j})}]^{2})\;\;-\;\;[{\mathbb{E}}(\sum_{j=1}^{N}\frac{U(w^{j},\phi)}{Nv(w^{j})})]^{2}
=\displaystyle= 1N‚Äã{‚à´ùëëw‚Äãv‚Äã(w)‚Äã[U‚Äã(w,œï)v‚Äã(w)]2‚àí[‚à´ùëëw‚Äãv‚Äã(w)‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)v‚Äã(w)]2}1ùëÅdifferential-dùë§ùë£ùë§superscriptdelimited-[]ùëàùë§italic-œïùë£ùë§2superscriptdelimited-[]differential-dùë§ùë£ùë§ùëàùë§italic-œïùë£ùë§2\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\{\int dw\;v(w)[\frac{U(w,\phi)}{v(w)}]^{2}\;\;-\;\;[\int dw\;v(w)\frac{U(w,\phi)}{v(w)}]^{2}\}
=\displaystyle= 1N‚Äã{‚à´ùëëw‚Äãv‚Äã(w)‚Äã[U‚Äã(w,œï)v‚Äã(w)]2‚àí[‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)]2}.1ùëÅdifferential-dùë§ùë£ùë§superscriptdelimited-[]ùëàùë§italic-œïùë£ùë§2superscriptdelimited-[]‚Ñíitalic-œï2\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\{\int dw\;v(w)[\frac{U(w,\phi)}{v(w)}]^{2}\;\;-\;\;[{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)]^{2}\}.

This expansion for the sample variance is quite useful. For example, one can solve for the vùë£v that minimizes this variance (and therefore minimizes expected loss) as a function of U(.,œï)U(.,\phi). For nowhere-negative UùëàU, that optimal vùë£v is given by ¬†(see Robert and Casella, 2004)

v‚Äã(w)‚âúU‚Äã(w,œï)‚à´ùëëw‚Ä≤‚ÄãU‚Äã(w‚Ä≤,œï).‚âúùë£ùë§ùëàùë§italic-œïdifferential-dsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤ùëàsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤italic-œïv(w)\triangleq\frac{U(w,\phi)}{\int dw^{\prime}U(w^{\prime},\phi)}.

Given the formula for the optimal vùë£v, one can estimate it from a current sample set, and then use the estimated optimal vùë£v for future sampling. This is what is done in the VEGAS Algorithm¬†(Lepage, 1978, 1980). Consideration of the sample variance has also led to algorithms that partition XùëãX and then run importance sampling on each partition element separately, for instance, stratified sampling¬†(Fishman, 1996). MC estimators that do not use strict importance sampling may introduce bias. However, if the variance is sufficiently reduced, expected quadratic error is reduced. This can be exploited to tradeoff bias and variance.

2.3.2 From MC to MCO

When we combine MC with parameter optimization in MCO, quantities like Var‚Äã(‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï))Var^‚Ñíitalic-œï{\mbox{Var}}({\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)) for one particular œïitalic-œï\phi are not the main objects of interest. Instead, we are interested in expected loss of our iterated MCO algorithm, which involves multiple œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs. So what is the appropriate loss function for analyzing MCO? From the very definition of (P2), it is clear that we want L‚Äã(œï,U)ùêøitalic-œïùëàL(\phi,U) to be minimized by the œïitalic-œï\phi that minimizes ‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)differential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï\int dw\;U(w,\phi). The simplest approach to doing this, which will be assumed from now on, stipulates that

L‚Äã(œï,U)=‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)=‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï),ùêøitalic-œïùëà‚Ñíitalic-œïdifferential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï\displaystyle L(\phi,U)\;\;=\;\;{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)\;\;=\;\;\int dw\;U(w,\phi), (4)

the same integral appearing in (P2). If we can solve (P2) exactly, then we will have produced the œïitalic-œï\phi with minimal value of this loss function.

Given this choice of loss function, expected loss in naive MCO is

ùîº‚Äã(L‚à£U,v)ùîºconditionalùêøùëàùë£\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}(L\mid U,v) =\displaystyle= ‚à´ùëëw1‚Äã‚Ä¶‚ÄãùëëwN‚Äã‚àèi=1Nv‚Äã(wi)‚Äã‚Ñí‚Äã(argminœï‚Äã[‚Ñí^v,U,{wi}‚Äã(œï)])differential-dsuperscriptùë§1‚Ä¶differential-dsuperscriptùë§ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÅùë£superscriptùë§ùëñ‚Ñísubscriptargminitalic-œïdelimited-[]subscript^‚Ñíùë£ùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œï\displaystyle\int dw^{1}\ldots dw^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v(w^{i}){\mathscr{L}}({\mbox{argmin}}_{\phi}[{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{v,U,\{w^{i}\}}(\phi)]) (5)
=\displaystyle= ‚à´ùëëw1‚Äã‚Ä¶‚ÄãùëëwN‚Äã‚àèi=1Nv‚Äã(wi)‚Äã‚à´ùëëw‚Ä≤‚ÄãU‚Äã(w‚Ä≤,argminœï‚Äã[‚àëj=1NU‚Äã(wi,œï)v‚Äã(wi)]).differential-dsuperscriptùë§1‚Ä¶differential-dsuperscriptùë§ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÅùë£superscriptùë§ùëñdifferential-dsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤ùëàsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤subscriptargminitalic-œïdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œïùë£superscriptùë§ùëñ\displaystyle\int dw^{1}\ldots dw^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v(w^{i})\int dw^{\prime}\;U(w^{\prime},{\mbox{argmin}}_{\phi}[\sum_{j=1}^{N}\frac{U(w^{i},\phi)}{v(w^{i})}]).

The optimal vùë£v for naive MCO is the one that minimizes ùîº‚Äã(L‚à£U,v)ùîºconditionalùêøùëàùë£{\mathbb{E}}(L\mid U,v). There is no direct relation between this vùë£v and the one that minimizes loss for some single œïitalic-œï\phi. In stark contrast to the MC analysis in Sec.¬†2.3.1, in addition to the sample variance Var‚Äã(‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï))Var^‚Ñíitalic-œï{\mbox{Var}}({\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)) for any single œïitalic-œï\phi, the expected loss ùîº‚Äã(L‚à£U,v)ùîºconditionalùêøùëàùë£{\mathbb{E}}(L\mid U,v) now also depends on moments coupling the distributions of ‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï)^‚Ñíitalic-œï\hat{\mathscr{L}}(\phi) for different œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs. Loosely speaking, the bias-variance tradeoff in Sec.¬†2.3.1 now becomes a more complicated bias-variance-covariance tradeoff. Now, setting wùë§w is more involved, but we can approach it as follows.

Expressing the expected loss slightly differently gives us an important insight. Note that each sample set {wi}superscriptùë§ùëñ\{w^{i}\} gives rise to an associated set of estimates for all œï‚ààŒ¶italic-œïŒ¶\phi\in\Phi. Call this (possibly infinite dimensional) vector of estimates l‚Üí‚Üíùëô\vec{l}, each of whose components is indexed by œïitalic-œï\phi and is an estimate for that particular œïitalic-œï\phi. Now, instead of computing expected loss by averaging over all possible sample sets, we average over all possible vectors l‚Üí‚Üíùëô\vec{l}. In order to do this, we need to specify the probability of each vector l‚Üí‚Üíùëô\vec{l}. Define

œÄv,U,Œ¶‚Äã(l‚Üí)subscriptùúãùë£ùëàŒ¶‚Üíùëô\displaystyle\pi_{v,U,\Phi}({\vec{l}}) ‚âú‚âú\displaystyle\triangleq Pr({wi}:‚Ñí^v,U,{wi}(œï)=lœï‚àÄœï‚ààŒ¶).\displaystyle{\mbox{Pr}}(\{w^{i}\}:{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{v,U,\{w^{i}\}}(\phi)=l_{\phi}\;\;\forall\phi\in\Phi).

So, œÄv,U,Œ¶‚Äã(l‚Üí)subscriptùúãùë£ùëàŒ¶‚Üíùëô\pi_{{}_{v,U,\Phi}}({\vec{l}}) is the probability of a set of sample points {wisuperscriptùë§ùëñw^{i}} such that for each œï‚ààŒ¶italic-œïŒ¶\phi\in\Phi, the associated empirical estimate ‚àëirv,U,wi‚Äã(œï)subscriptùëñsubscriptùëüùë£ùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œï\sum_{i}r_{v,U,w^{i}}(\phi) equals the corresponding component of l‚Üí‚Üíùëô\vec{l}. For notational simplicity the subscripts of œÄv,U,Œ¶subscriptùúãùë£ùëàŒ¶\pi_{{}_{v,U,\Phi}} will sometimes be omitted. We can now write Eq.¬†5 succinctly as

ùîº‚Äã(L‚à£U,v)ùîºconditionalùêøùëàùë£\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}(L\mid U,v) =\displaystyle= ‚à´ùëël‚Üí‚ÄãœÄ‚Äã(l‚Üí)‚Äã‚Ñí‚Äã(argminœï‚Äã[lœï])differential-d‚Üíùëôùúã‚Üíùëô‚Ñísubscriptargminitalic-œïdelimited-[]subscriptùëôitalic-œï\displaystyle\int d{\vec{l}}\;\pi({\vec{l}})\;{\mathscr{L}}({\mbox{argmin}}_{\phi}[l_{\phi}]) (6)

where ‚Äòargmin[lœï]œï{}_{\phi}[l_{\phi}]‚Äô means the index œïitalic-œï\phi of the smallest component of l‚Üí‚Üíùëô\vec{l}. The risk is the difference between this expected loss and the lowest possible loss. We can write that risk as

‚à´ùëël‚Üí‚ÄãœÄv,U,Œ¶‚Äã(l‚Üí)‚Äã[‚Ñí‚Äã(argminœï‚Äã[lœï])‚àíminœï‚Äã[‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)]].differential-d‚Üíùëôsubscriptùúãùë£ùëàŒ¶‚Üíùëôdelimited-[]‚Ñísubscriptargminitalic-œïdelimited-[]subscriptùëôitalic-œïsubscriptminitalic-œïdelimited-[]‚Ñíitalic-œï\displaystyle\int d{\vec{l}}\;\pi_{v,U,\Phi}({\vec{l}})\;[{\mathscr{L}}({\mbox{argmin}}_{\phi}[l_{\phi}])\;-\;{\mbox{min}}_{\phi}[{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)]]. (7)

Our sample set constitutes a set of samples of œÄv,U,Œ¶subscriptùúãùë£ùëàŒ¶\pi_{v,U,\Phi} occurring in Eq.¬†6,This fact can potentially be exploited to dynamically modify vùë£v and/or Œ¶Œ¶\Phi to reduce ùîº‚Äã(L‚à£U,v)ùîºconditionalùêøùëàùë£{\mathbb{E}}(L\mid U,v). Indeed, for the simpler case of MC estimation, this is essentially the kind of computation done in the VEGAS algorithm mentioned above. As a practical issue, it may be difficult to update vùë£v and/or Œ¶Œ¶\Phi using the full formula Eq.¬†5. Instead, one could approximate that formula ùîº‚Äã(L‚à£U,v)ùîºconditionalùêøùëàùë£{\mathbb{E}}(L\mid U,v) near a single œïitalic-œï\phi of interest, e.g., about a current estimate for the optimal œïitalic-œï\phi.

Intuitively though, one would expect that for a fixed set of œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs, everything else being equal, it would be advantageous to have small variances of unbiased estimators and large covariances between them. Such considerations based on the second moments may help one choose quantities like the sampling distribution vùë£v.

Such considerations may also help one choose the set of candidate œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs, Œ¶Œ¶\Phi. For example, one way to have large covariances between the œï‚ààŒ¶italic-œïŒ¶\phi\in\Phi is to have the associated functions over wùë§w, {U(.,œï):œï‚ààŒ¶}U(.,\phi):\phi\in\Phi\}, all lie close to one another in an appropriate function space (e.g., according to an l‚àûsubscriptùëôl_{\infty} norm comparing such functions). However, choosing such a Œ¶Œ¶\Phi will tend to mean there is a small ‚Äòcoverage‚Äô of that set of functions, {U(.,œï):œï‚ààŒ¶}U(.,\phi):\phi\in\Phi\}. More precisely, it will tend to prevent the best of those œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs from being very good; min[‚à´dwU(w,œï)]œï‚ààŒ¶{}_{\phi\in\Phi}[\int dw\;U(w,\phi)] will not be very low.

This illustrates that, in choosing Œ¶Œ¶\Phi, there will be a tradeoff between two quantities: The first quantity is the best possible performance with any of the œï‚ààŒ¶italic-œïŒ¶\phi\in\Phi. The second quantity is the risk, that is, how close a given MCO algorithm operating on Œ¶Œ¶\Phi is likely to come to that best possible performance of a member of Œ¶Œ¶\Phi. Choosing Œ¶Œ¶\Phi to have large covariances of the (MC estimators based on the) members of Œ¶Œ¶\Phi, and in particular to have large covariances with the truly optimal œïitalic-œï\phi, argmin‚Ñíœï‚ààŒ¶‚Äã(œï)subscript‚Ñíitalic-œïŒ¶italic-œï{}_{\phi\in\Phi}{\mathscr{L}}(\phi), will tend to result in low risk. But it will also tend to result in poor best-possible performance over all œï‚ààŒ¶italic-œïŒ¶\phi\in\Phi.

Similarly, one would expect that as the size of Œ¶Œ¶\Phi increases, there would be a greater chance that a sample set for one of the suboptimal œï‚ààŒ¶italic-œïŒ¶\phi\in\Phi would have low expected loss ‚Äòby luck‚Äô. This would then mislead one into choosing that suboptimal œïitalic-œï\phi. So increasing the size of Œ¶Œ¶\Phi may increase risk. However increasing Œ¶Œ¶\Phi‚Äôs size should also improve best possible performance. So again, we get a tradeoff.

It may be that such considerations involving the size of Œ¶Œ¶\Phi and the covariances of its members can be encapsulated in a single number, giving an ‚Äòeffective size‚Äô of Œ¶Œ¶\Phi (somewhat analogously to the VC dimension of a set of functions). Such tradeoffs are specific to the use of MCO, and do not arise in plain (single-œïitalic-œï\phi) MC. They are in addition to the usual bias-variance tradeoffs, which still apply to each of the separate MC estimators.

An illustrative example of the foregoing is provided in App.¬†C. A more complete statistical analysis of risk in MCO, including Bayesian considerations, is in Sec.¬†6.

2.4 PL Equals MCO

In MCO, we have to extrapolate from the sample set of wùë§w values to perform the integral minimization in Eq.¬†3. As discussed above, this can recast as having a set of sample functions œï‚Üíri‚Äã(œï)‚Üíitalic-œïsuperscriptùëüùëñitalic-œï\phi\rightarrow r^{i}(\phi) that we want to use to estimate the œïitalic-œï\phi that achieves that minimization. Similarly, in PL, we have to extrapolate from a training set of functions Ri‚Äã(Œæ)superscriptùëÖùëñùúâR^{i}(\xi) to minimize the integral ‚à´ùëëx‚ÄãP‚Äã(x)‚ÄãRx‚Äã(Œæ)differential-dùë•ùëÉùë•subscriptùëÖùë•ùúâ\int dx\;P(x)R_{x}(\xi). Though not usually viewed this way, at the root of this extrapolation problem is the problem of using the sample functions Œæ‚ÜíRi‚Äã(Œæ)‚ÜíùúâsuperscriptùëÖùëñùúâ\xi\rightarrow R^{i}(\xi) to estimate the minimizer of Eq.¬†2.

In addition, the analysis of Sec.¬†2.3 is closely related to the PL field of uniform convergence theory. That field can be cast in the terms of the current discussion as considering a broad class of UùëàU‚Äôs, ùí∞ùí∞\mathscr{U}. Its starting point is the establishment of bounds on how

depends333As an example, rewrite w‚Üíx,œï‚ÜíŒ±,v‚Äã(x)‚ÜíP‚Äã(x)formulae-sequence‚Üíùë§ùë•formulae-sequence‚Üíitalic-œïùõº‚Üíùë£ùë•ùëÉùë•w\rightarrow x,\phi\rightarrow\alpha,v(x)\rightarrow P(x). Of particular interest is how the function taking Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa to the associated bound varies with characteristics of ùí∞ùí∞\mathscr{U} and Œ¶Œ¶\Phi¬†(see Vapnik, 1982, 1995). Eq.¬†8 should be compared with Eq.¬†7.

All of this suggests that the general MCO problem of extrapolation from a sample set of empirical functions to minimize the integral of Eq.¬†3, is, in fact, identical to the general PL problem of extrapolation from a training set of empirical functions to minimize the integral of Eq.¬†2. This is indeed the case. As shown in Table¬†1, identify Œæ‚Üîœï,x‚Üîw,P‚Äã(x)‚Üîv‚Äã(w),Rx‚Äã(Œæ)‚Üîrv,w‚Äã(œï),rvi‚Äã(œï)‚ÜîRi‚Äã(Œæ)‚Üîùúâitalic-œïùë•‚Üîùë§ùëÉùë•‚Üîùë£ùë§subscriptùëÖùë•ùúâ‚Üîsubscriptùëüùë£ùë§italic-œïsubscriptsuperscriptùëüùëñùë£italic-œï‚ÜîsuperscriptùëÖùëñùúâ\xi\leftrightarrow\phi,x\leftrightarrow w,P(x)\leftrightarrow v(w),R_{x}(\xi)\leftrightarrow{r}_{v,w}(\phi),r^{i}_{v}(\phi)\leftrightarrow R^{i}(\xi). Then the integrals in Eq.¬†3 and (P1) become identical. So the MCO expected loss function in Eq.¬†4 becomes identical to the PL expected loss. Similarly, the sample functions for MCO and PL become identical.

In particular, in supervised learning, when there is no noise, P‚Äã(y‚à£x)ùëÉconditionalùë¶ùë•P(y\mid x) becomes a single-valued function y‚Äã(x)ùë¶ùë•y(x), and the parametric supervised learning problem becomes

argminŒæ‚Äã‚à´ùëëx‚ÄãP‚Äã(x)‚Äã[L‚Äã(y‚Äã(x),zŒæ‚Äã(x))]subscriptargminùúâdifferential-dùë•ùëÉùë•delimited-[]ùêøùë¶ùë•subscriptùëßùúâùë•\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{\xi}\int dx\;P(x)[L(y(x),z_{\xi}(x))]

This should be compared to the MCO problem as formulated in Eq.¬†3. For the same reasons that direct minimization of Eq.¬†1 is seldom used in PL, we now see that naive MCO will be biased, and should preferably not be used directly.

Note that most sampling theory analysis of PL does not directly consider the biases and variances of the separate Monte Carlo estimators for each Œæùúâ\xi, nor does it directly consider the moments that couple the distributions of those estimates. Rather, it considers a different type of bias and variance ‚Äî the bias and variance of an entire algorithm that chooses a Œæùúâ\xi based on associated MC estimates of expected loss¬†(Wolpert, 1997). In this sense, such PL analysis bypasses the issues considered in Sec.¬†2.3. The bias-variance-covariance approach described in this section might have important implications on PL analysis of learning algorithms, but for the moment, in our exploration of the identity between MCO and PL, we simply use PL-based techniques to reduce the bias or variance of our algorithms.

3 Review of PC

This section cursorily reviews the previously investigated type of PC. It then briefly discusses the advantages of PC for blackbox optimization and its relation to other blackbox optimization techniques.

3.1 Introduction to PC

To introduce PC, consider the general (not necessarily blackbox) optimization problem

(P4)::P4absent\displaystyle\mathrm{(P4):} argminx‚ààX‚Äãùîº‚Äã(g‚à£x,ùí¢).subscriptargminùë•ùëãùîºconditionalùëîùë•ùí¢\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{x\in X}{\mathbb{E}}(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}).

For now, we ignore constraints on xùë•x. In PC we transform (P4) into the problem

(P5)::P5absent\displaystyle\mathrm{(P5):} argminqŒ∏‚ààùí¨‚Äã‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(qŒ∏),subscriptargminsubscriptùëûùúÉùí¨subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢subscriptùëûùúÉ\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{q_{\theta}\in{\mathscr{Q}}}{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}),

for some appropriate function ‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}. After solving (P5) we stochastically invert qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} to get an xùë•x (the ultimate object of interest), by sampling qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}. This type of ‚Äúrandomizing transform‚Äù contrasts with conventional transform techniques, where inversion is deterministic.

Ideally, ‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}} should be chosen in a first-principles manner, based on exactly how qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} will be sampled and how those samples used (see Sec.¬†6). In practice though, computational considerations might lead one to choose ‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}} heuristically. Intuitively, such considerations might compel us to choose ‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}} both so that (P5) is readily easy to solve, and so that any solution qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} to (P5) is concentrated about the solutions of (P4). Taking the parametrization to be implicit, we often abbreviate ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢subscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}) as just ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta).

To see why this choice of ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) is reasonable, first note that pŒ≤‚Äã(x)superscriptùëùùõΩùë•p^{\beta}(x) is large where G‚Äã(x)ùê∫ùë•G(x) is small. Now, suppose that ùí¨ùí¨{\mathscr{Q}} is a broad enough class that it can approximate any sufficiently peaked distribution. That means that there is a qŒ∏‚ààùí¨subscriptùëûùúÉùí¨q_{\theta}\in{\mathscr{Q}} for which KL(pŒ≤||qŒ∏){\mbox{KL}}(p^{\beta}\;||\;q_{\theta}) is small for large Œ≤ùõΩ\beta. In such a situation, the qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} solving (P5) will be highly peaked about the xùë•x(s) solving (P4). Accordingly, if we can solve (P5) for large Œ≤ùõΩ\beta, sampling the resultant qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} will result in an xùë•x with a low ùîº‚Äã(g‚à£x,ùí¢)ùîºconditionalùëîùë•ùí¢{\mathbb{E}}(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}).

3.2 Review of Delayed Sampling

We now present a review of conventional, delayed-sampling PC. In this type of PC we exploit characteristics of the parametrization of qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}, and pursue the algebraic solution of (P5) as far as possible, in closed form. At some point, if there remain quantities in this algebraic expression that we cannot evaluate closed-form, we estimate them using Monte Carlo sampling.

As an example, consider a noise-free oracle, and instead of p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq Kullback-Leibler distance, choose ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢subscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}) to be the expected value returned by the oracle under qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta},

ùîºqŒ∏,ùí¢‚Äã(g)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùí¢ùëî\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},{\mathscr{G}}}(g) ‚âú‚âú\displaystyle\triangleq ‚à´ùëëx‚Äãùëëg‚Äãg‚ÄãP‚Äã(g‚à£x,ùí¢)‚ÄãqŒ∏‚Äã(x)differential-dùë•differential-dùëîùëîùëÉconditionalùëîùë•ùí¢subscriptùëûùúÉùë•\displaystyle\int dx\,dg\;gP(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}})q_{\theta}(x) (11)
=\displaystyle= ‚à´ùëëx‚ÄãG‚Äã(x)‚ÄãqŒ∏‚Äã(x)differential-dùë•ùê∫ùë•subscriptùëûùúÉùë•\displaystyle\int dx\;G(x)q_{\theta}(x)

where the second equality reflects the fact that we are assuming a noise-free oracle. To emphasize the fact that we‚Äôre considering noise-free oracles555Even though it is noise-free, the oracle Gùê∫G may be a random variable ‚Äî we may not know Gùê∫G, and may attempt to predict it probabilistically from data, in a Bayesian fashion. In such a situation, notation like ‚Äòùîº‚Äã(ùí¢)ùîºùí¢{\mathbb{E}}({\mathscr{G}})‚Äô refers to the expected oracle under our prior distribution over oracles. So, we use ùîºqŒ∏,G‚Äã(g)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫ùëî{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},G}(g) rather than ùîºqŒ∏‚Äã(G)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta}}(G), even though the latter is the notation we used in previous work on PC., we will sometimes write ùîºqŒ∏,ùí¢‚Äã(g)=ùîºqŒ∏,G‚Äã(g)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùí¢ùëîsubscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫ùëî{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},{\mathscr{G}}}(g)={\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},G}(g). While ùîºqŒ∏,ùí¢‚Äã(g)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùí¢ùëî{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},{\mathscr{G}}}(g) is a linear function of qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}, in general it will not be a linear function of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. Accordingly, finding the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta minimizing ùîºqŒ∏,ùí¢‚Äã(g)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùí¢ùëî{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},{\mathscr{G}}}(g) may be a non-trivial optimization problem.

Since qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} must be a probability distribution, (P5) is actually a constrained optimization problem, involving |X|ùëã|X| inequality constraints {qŒ∏‚Äã(x)‚â•0‚Äã‚àÄxsubscriptùëûùúÉùë•0for-allùë•q_{\theta}(x)\geq 0\;\forall x}, and one equality constraint, ‚à´ùëëx‚ÄãqŒ∏‚Äã(x)=1differential-dùë•subscriptùëûùúÉùë•1\int dx\;q_{\theta}(x)=1. As discussed by¬†Wolpert et¬†al. (2006), such a constrained optimization problem can be converted into one with no inequality constraints by the use of barrier function methods. These methods transform the original optimization problem into a sequence of new optimization problems, {(P5)i}, each of which is easier to solve than the original problem (P5). Solving those problems in sequence leads to a solution to the original problem (P5).

Consider applying this method with an entropic barrier for the case where ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(qŒ∏)=ùîºqŒ∏,G‚Äã(g)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢subscriptùëûùúÉsubscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫ùëî{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta})={\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},G}(g). Then, it turns out that up to additive constants, each problem (P5)i is again of the form of (P5). However the ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢subscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}) of each problem (P5)i is the ‚Äòq‚Äãpùëûùëùqp‚Äô KL distance, KL(qŒ∏||pŒ≤i)(q_{\theta}\;||\;p^{\beta_{i}}), where Œ≤isubscriptùõΩùëñ\beta_{i} is the value of the ‚Äòbarrier parameter‚Äô specifying problem (P5)i. In other words, up to irrelevant additive constants, each (P5)i is the problem of finding the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta that minimizes

‚Ñ±G,Œ≤i‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫subscriptùõΩùëñsubscriptùëûùúÉ\displaystyle{\mathscr{F}}_{G,{\beta_{i}}}(q_{\theta}) =\displaystyle= ùîºqŒ∏,G‚Äã(g)‚àíŒ≤i‚àí1‚ÄãS‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫ùëîsuperscriptsubscriptùõΩùëñ1ùëÜsubscriptùëûùúÉ\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},G}(g)-{\beta_{i}}^{-1}S(q_{\theta})

where S(.)S(.) is conventional Shannon entropy666This q‚Äãpùëûùëùqp distance is just the free energy of qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} for Hamiltonian function Gùê∫G and inverse temperature Œ≤isubscriptùõΩùëñ\beta_{i}. This gives a novel derivation of the physics injunction to minimize the free energy of a system.. In this case the barrier function method directs us to iterate the following process: Solve for the qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} that minimizes KL(qŒ∏||pŒ≤i)(q_{\theta}\;||\;p^{\beta_{i}}), and then update Œ≤isubscriptùõΩùëñ\beta_{i}. At the end of this process we will have a local solution to (P5).

In the case where XùëãX is a Cartesian product, we often use distributions parametrized as a product distribution, qŒ∏=‚àèiqi‚Äã(xi)subscriptùëûùúÉsubscriptproductùëñsubscriptùëûùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñq_{\theta}=\prod_{i}q_{i}(x_{i}). Under this parametrization each problem (P5)i can be solved by gradient descent, where the gradient components of ‚Ñ±G,Œ≤i‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫subscriptùõΩùëñsubscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G,{\beta_{i}}}(q_{\theta}) are given by

where the Lagrange parameters ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i} enforce normalization of each qisubscriptùëûùëñq_{i}.

There are many better alternatives777One of these alternatives can be cast as a corrected version of the replicator dynamics of evolutionary game theory¬†(Wolpert, 2004b). This may have interesting implications for GAs, which presume evolutionary processes. to simple gradient descent for minimizing each ‚Ñ±G,Œ≤i‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫subscriptùõΩùëñsubscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G,{\beta_{i}}}(q_{\theta}), involving Newton‚Äôs method, block relaxation, and related techniques¬†(Wolpert et¬†al., 2006). In all such schemes investigated to date, we need to repeatedly evaluate terms like ùîºqŒ∏,G‚Äã(g‚à£xi)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫conditionalùëîsubscriptùë•ùëñ{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},G}(g\mid x_{i}). Sometimes that evaluation can be done closed form¬†(Macready and Wolpert, 2005, 2004). In blackbox optimization though, this is not possible.

Typically, when we cannot evaluate the terms ùîºqŒ∏,G‚Äã(g‚à£xi)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫conditionalùëîsubscriptùë•ùëñ{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},G}(g\mid x_{i}) in closed-form we use MC to estimate them. Since we have a product distribution, we can generate samples of the joint distribution qŒ∏‚Äã(x)subscriptùëûùúÉùë•q_{\theta}(x) by sampling each of the marginals qi‚Äã(xi)subscriptùëûùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñq_{i}(x_{i}) separately. One can use those sample xùë•x‚Äôs as queries to the oracle. Then, by appropriately averaging the oracle‚Äôs responses to those queries, one can estimate each term ùîºqŒ∏,G‚Äã(g‚à£xi)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫conditionalùëîsubscriptùë•ùëñ{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},G}(g\mid x_{i})¬†(Wolpert and Bieniawski, 2004). The product factorization implies that our iterative procedure can be performed in a completely decentralized manner, with a separate program controlling each component xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}, and communicating only with the oracle888Each such program may be thought of as an ‚Äòagent‚Äô who updates his probability distribution, and this ‚Äòcollective‚Äô of agents performs optimization in a decentralized manner. This led to the name ‚ÄòProbability Collective‚Äô..

In this scheme, once qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} is modified, samples of the oracle that were generated from preceding qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}‚Äôs can no longer be directly used to estimate the terms ùîºqŒ∏,G‚Äã(g‚à£xi)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫conditionalùëîsubscriptùë•ùëñ{\mathbb{E}}_{q_{\theta},G}(g\mid x_{i}). However, there are several ‚Äòdata-aging‚Äô heuristics one can employ to reuse such old data by down-weighting it.

In all these schemes, while we ultimately use Monte Carlo in the PC, it is delayed as long as possible in the course of solving (P5). This is the basis for calling this variant of PC ‚Äòdelayed sampling‚Äô.

3.3 Advantages of PC

The PC transformation can substantially alter the optimization landscape. For a noise-free oracle G‚Äã(x)ùê∫ùë•G(x), (P4) reduces to the problem of finding the xùë•x that minimizes G‚Äã(x)ùê∫ùë•G(x). In contrast, (P5) is the problem of finding the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta that minimizes ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta). The characteristics of the problems of minimizing G‚Äã(x)ùê∫ùë•G(x) and minimizing ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) can be vastly different. For example, suppose qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} is log-concave in its parameters, and ‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}} is p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq KL distance. In this case, regardless of the function G‚Äã(x)ùê∫ùë•G(x), ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) is a convex function of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, over ùí¨ùí¨{\mathscr{Q}}. So the PC transformation converts a problem with potentially many local minima into a problem with none. See¬†Wolpert et¬†al. (2006) for a discussion of the geometry of the surface ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏):Œ∏‚Üí‚Ñù:subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ‚ÜíùúÉ‚Ñù{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta):\theta\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}}.

Since it works directly on distributions, PC can handle arbitrary data types. XùëãX can be categorical, real-valued, integer-valued, or a mixture of all of these, but in each case, the distribution over XùëãX is parametrized by a vector of real numbers. This means that all such problems ‚Äòlook the same‚Äô to much of the mathematics of PC. Moreover, PC can exploit extremely well-understood techniques (like gradient descent) for optimization of continuous functions of real-valued vectors, and apply them to problems in these arbitrary spaces.

Optimizing over distributions can give sensitivity information: The distribution qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} produced in PC will typically be tightly peaked along certain directions, while being relatively flat along other directions. This tells us the relative importance of getting the value of xùë•x along those different directions precisely correct.

We can set the initial distribution for PC to be a sum of broad peaks, each centered on a solution produced by some other optimization algorithm. Then, as that initial distribution gets updated in the PC algorithm, the set of solutions provided by those other optimization algorithms are in essence combined, to produce a solution that should be superior to any of them individually.

Yet another advantage to optimizing a distribution is that a distribution can easily provide multiple solutions to the optimization problem, potentially far apart in XùëãX. Those solutions can then be compared by the analyst in a qualitative fashion.

As discussed later, there are other advantages that accrue specifically if one uses the immediate-sampling variant of PC. These include the ability to reuse all old data, the ability to exploit prior knowledge concerning the oracle, and the ability to leverage PL techniques. See¬†Wolpert et¬†al. (2006) for a discussion of other advantages of PC, in particular in the context of distributed control.

3.4 Relation to Other Work

PC is related to several other optimization techniques. Consider, for instance, Response Surface Models (RSM)s¬†Jones et¬†al. (1998). In these techniques, one uses Design of Experiments (DOE) to evaluate the objective function at a set of points. Then, a low-order parametric function, often a quadratic, is fitted to these function values. Optimization of this ‚Äòresponse surface‚Äô or ‚Äòsurrogate model‚Äô is considered trivial compared to the original optimization. The result of this surrogate optimization is then used to get more samples of the true objective at a different set of points. This procedure is then iterated using some heuristics, often in conjunction with trust-region methods to ensure validity of the low-order approximation. We note the similarities with PC in Table¬†2.

As another example, some variants of PC exploit MC techniques as discussed above, and thus stochastically generate populations of samples. In their use of random populations these variants of PC are similar to simulated annealing¬†(Kirkpatrick et¬†al., 1983), and even more so to techniques like EDA‚Äôs¬†Larraaga and Lozano (2001); De¬†Bonet et¬†al. (1997); Lozano et¬†al. (2005) and the CE method¬†(Rubinstein and Kroese, 2004). However, these other approaches do not explicitly pursue the optimization of the underlying distribution qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}, as in (P5). Accordingly, those approaches cannot exploit situations in which (P5) can be solved without using a stochastically generated population¬†(Macready and Wolpert, 2005, 2004). See¬†Macready and Wolpert (2005) for a more extensive discussion of the relation of PC to other techniques.

4 Immediate sampling

This section introduces a new PC technique called immediate sampling, and cursorily compares it to delayed sampling. As we have just described, in delayed sampling, we use algebra for as long as possible in our solution of (P5). When closed-form expressions can no longer be evaluated, we resort to MC techniques. In immediate sampling, we form an MC sample immediately, rather than delaying it as long as possible. That sample gives us an approximation to our objective, ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ\mathscr{F}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) for all Œ∏‚ààùí¨ùúÉùí¨\theta\in{\mathscr{Q}}. We then search for the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta that optimizes that sample-based approximate objective.

4.2 Immediate Sampling with Multiple Sample Sets

In general, we will not end the algorithm after forming a single sample set D1superscriptùê∑1D^{1}. Instead we will use a map Œ∑ùúÇ\eta that takes D1superscriptùê∑1D^{1} to a new sampling distribution, h2superscript‚Ñé2h^{2}. We then generate new (x,g)ùë•ùëî(x,g) pairs using h2superscript‚Ñé2h^{2}, giving us a new sample set D2superscriptùê∑2D^{2}. We then iterate this process until we decide to end the algorithm, at which point we use all our samples sets together to estimate argmin‚Ñ±ùí¢Œ∏‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscriptsubscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉsubscriptùëûùúÉ{}_{\theta}{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}).

Say we have fixed on some such Œ∏ùúÉ\theta-estimation procedure to run at the end of the algorithm. The final step of each iteration of immediate sampling is to run Œ∑ùúÇ\eta, the map taking the samples generated so far to a new h‚Ñéh. Ideally, we want to use the Œ∑ùúÇ\eta that, when repeatedly run during the algorithm, maximizes the expected accuracy of the final Œ∏ùúÉ\theta-estimation. However even for a simple Œ∏ùúÉ\theta-estimation procedure, determining this optimal Œ∑ùúÇ\eta can be quite difficult. As discussed later, it is identical to the active learning problem in machine learning.

In this paper we adopt a two-step heuristic for setting Œ∑ùúÇ\eta. In the first step, at the end of each iteration, we estimate the optimal qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} based on all the sample sets generated so far, using Eq.¬†15. In the second step, we complete Œ∑ùúÇ\eta by setting the new h‚Ñéh to the current estimate of the optimal qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}. At that point, the new h‚Ñéh is used to generate a new sample set, and the process repeats.

4.3 Immediate Sampling with MCMC

For certain types of ‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}, it is possible to form samples using other sampling methods like Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC)¬†(see Mackay, 2003; Bernardo and Smith, 2000; Berger, 1985). For example, if ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) is p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq distance from the Boltzmann distribution pŒ≤superscriptùëùùõΩp^{\beta} to qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}, then we can use MCMC to form a sample set of pŒ≤superscriptùëùùõΩp^{\beta} (not of qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}). We can then use that sample set to form an unbiased estimate of ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) for any Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. But if Œ≤ùõΩ\beta were to change, these old samples cannot be used directly. One would have to resort to additional techniques like rejection sampling in order to reuse these samples. The advantage of using importance sampling is that all previous samples can be reused by the simple expedient of modifying their likelihood ratios. Therefore, in this paper, we only consider sampling distributions h‚Ñéh that can be sampled directly, without any need for techniques like MCMC.

4.4 Advantages of Immediate-Sampling PC

In contrast to delayed sampling, immediate sampling usually presents no difficulty with reusing old data, as shown above; all (xi,j,gi,j)superscriptùë•ùëñùëósuperscriptùëîùëñùëó(x^{i,j},g^{i,j}) pairs can be used directly. Note that we can also reuse data that was generated when FùêπF was different, for instance, data generated under a differerent Œ≤isuperscriptùõΩùëñ\beta^{i} during a KL distance minimization procedure. As long as we store hj‚Äã(xi,j)superscript‚Ñéùëósuperscriptùë•ùëñùëóh^{j}(x^{i,j}) in addition to gi,jsuperscriptùëîùëñùëóg^{i,j} and xi,jsuperscriptùë•ùëñùëóx^{i,j} for every sample, we can always evaluate rhji,j‚Äã(xi,j,Œ∏)subscriptsuperscriptùëüùëñùëósuperscript‚Ñéùëósuperscriptùë•ùëñùëóùúÉr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta) for any FùêπF.

Indeed, we can even comment on optimal ways of reusing this old data. Since each rhji,j‚Äã(xi,j,Œ∏)subscriptsuperscriptùëüùëñùëósuperscript‚Ñéùëósuperscriptùë•ùëñùëóùúÉr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta) is an unbiased estimate of the integral ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta), any weighted average of the rhji,j‚Äã(xi,j,Œ∏)subscriptsuperscriptùëüùëñùëósuperscript‚Ñéùëósuperscriptùë•ùëñùëóùúÉr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta)‚Äôs is also an unbiased estimate. This can be exploited in the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta-estimation procedure. For instance, consider the estimator of Eq.¬†15. If we have good estimates of the variances of the individual rhji,j‚Äã(xi,j,Œ∏)subscriptsuperscriptùëüùëñùëósuperscript‚Ñéùëósuperscriptùë•ùëñùëóùúÉr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta), we can weight the terms rhji,j‚Äã(xi,j,Œ∏)subscriptsuperscriptùëüùëñùëósuperscript‚Ñéùëósuperscriptùë•ùëñùëóùúÉr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta) to minimize the variance of the associated weighted average estimator. Those weights are proportional to the inverses of the variances¬†(see Macready and Wolpert, 2005; Lepage, 1978, 1980). As discussed in Sec.¬†2.3, the accuracy of the associated MCO algorithm could be expected to improve under such weighting.

We can also shed light on how to go about gathering new data. As in the VEGAS Algorithm¬†(Lepage, 1978, 1980), one could incorporate bias-variance considerations into the operator Œ∑ùúÇ\eta that sets the next sampling distribution. To give an example, let ŒûŒû\Xi be the range of Œ∑ùúÇ\eta, and fix Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. Given ŒûŒû\Xi and Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, one can ask what proposal distribution h‚ààŒû‚ÑéŒûh\in\Xi would minimize the sample variance of the estimator in Eq.¬†14. Intuitively, this is akin to asking how best to do active learning. In general, the answer to this question, the optimal sampling distribution h‚Äã(x)‚Ñéùë•h(x), will be set by the function rP‚Äã(g‚à£x,ùí¢),h‚Äã(Œ∏)subscriptùëüùëÉconditionalùëîùë•ùí¢‚ÑéùúÉr_{P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}),h}(\theta), viewed as mapping X‚Üí‚Ñù‚Üíùëã‚ÑùX\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}}. Accordingly, for any fixed Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, one can use the MC samples generated so far to estimate the xùë•x-dependence of rP‚Äã(g‚à£x,ùí¢),h‚Äã(Œ∏)subscriptùëüùëÉconditionalùëîùë•ùí¢‚ÑéùúÉr_{P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}),h}(\theta), and thereby estimate the optimal h‚ààŒû‚ÑéŒûh\in\Xi. One then uses that estimate as the next sampling distribution h‚Ñéh.

Another advantage of immediate sampling over delayed sampling is that the analysis in delayed sampling relies crucially on the parametrization of the qùëûq‚Äôs; some such parametrizations will permit the closed-form calculations of delayed sampling, and others will not. In immediate sampling, this problem disappears.

4.5 Implications of the Identity Between MCO and PL

For the case where ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{{\mathscr{G}}}(\theta) is an integral transform like Eq.¬†9, the PC optimization problem (P5) becomes a special case of minimizing a parametrized integral, the problem (P2). Formally, the equivalence is made by equating xùë•x with the parameter œïitalic-œï\phi, gùëîg with wùë§w, and g√óP‚Äã(g‚à£x,ùí¢)ùëîùëÉconditionalùëîùë•ùí¢g\times P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}) with U‚Äã(w,œï)ùëàùë§italic-œïU(w,\phi). In particular, immediate sampling is a special case of MCO. This identity means that we can exploit the extremely well-researched field of PL to improve many aspects of immediate sampling. In particular:

  • ‚Ä¢

    PL techniques like boosting¬†(Schapire and Singer, 1999) and bagging¬†(Breiman, 1994) can be used in (re)using old samples before forming new ones.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Variants of active learning101010Active learning in the precise machine learning sense uses current data to decide on a new query xùë•x to feed to the oracle. We use the term more loosely here, to refer to any scheme for using current data to dynamically modify a process for generating for future queries. can be used to set and update h‚Ñéh. Some aspect of this are discussed in Sec.¬†6 below.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Cross-validation is directly applicable in many ways: In our context, the curse of dimensionality arises if ùí¨ùí¨{\mathscr{Q}} is very large. We can address this the conventional PL way, by adding a regularization function of qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} to the objective function. The parameters controlling this regularization can be updated dynamically, as new data is generated, using cross-validation

    To use cross-validation this way, one forms multiple partitions of the current data. For each such partition, one calculates the optimal qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} for the training subset of that partition. One then examines error on the validation subset of that partition. More precisely, one calculates the unregularized objective value on the held-out data.

  • ‚Ä¢

    More generally, we can use cross-validation to dynamically update any parameters of the immediate sampling algorithm. For example, we can update the ‚Äòtemperature‚Äô parameter Œ≤ùõΩ\beta of the Boltzmann distribution, arising in both q‚Äãpùëûùëùqp and p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq KL distance, this way.

    Note that doing this does not involve making more calls to the oracle.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We can also use cross-validation to choose the best model class (parametrization) for qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}, among several candidates.

  • ‚Ä¢

    As an alternative to all these uses of cross-validation, one can use stacking to dynamically combine differrent temperatures, different parametrized density functions, and so on.

  • ‚Ä¢

    One may also be able to apply kernel methods to do the density estimation¬†(see Macready, 2005).

5 Experiments

In this section, we demonstrate the application of PL and immediate-sampling PC techniques to the unconstrained optimization of continuous functions, both deterministic and nondeterministic. We first describe our choice of ‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢\mathscr{F}_{\mathscr{G}}, in this case p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq KL distance. Next, as an illustrative example, we apply immediate sampling to the simplest of optimization problems, where the objective is a 2-D quadratic. Subsequently, we apply it to deterministic and stochastic versions of two well-known unconstrained optimization benchmarks, the Rosenbrock function and the Woods function.

We highlight the use of PL techniques to enhance optimizer performance on these benchmark problems. In particular, we show that cross-validation for regularization yields a performance improvement of an order of magnitude. We then show that cross-validation for model-selection results in improved performance, especially in the early stages of the algorithm. We also show that bagging can yield significant improvements in performance.

5.1 Minimizing p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq KL Distance

Recall that the integral form of p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq KL distance is

KL‚Äã(p‚à•q)=‚à´ùëëx‚Äãp‚Äã(x)‚Äãln‚Å°(p‚Äã(x)q‚Äã(x)).KLconditionalùëùùëûdifferential-dùë•ùëùùë•ùëùùë•ùëûùë•\textrm{KL}(p\|q)=\int dx\,p(x)\ln\left(\frac{p(x)}{q(x)}\right).

It is easy to show that when there are no restrictions on qùëûq being a parametrized density, p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq KL distance is minimized if p=qùëùùëûp=q. However, owing to sampling considerations, we usually choose qùëûq to be some parametric distribution qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}. In this case, we want to find the parameter vector Œ∏ùúÉ\theta that minimizes KL(p‚à•qŒ∏)conditionalùëùsubscriptùëûùúÉ(p\|q_{\theta}). Since the target distribution pùëùp is derived purely from ùí¢ùí¢\mathscr{G} and is independent of qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}, minimizing p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq KL distance is equivalent to the following cross-entropy minimization problem.

minimize‚àí‚à´ùëëx‚Äãp‚Äã(x)‚Äãln‚Å°(q‚Äã(x)),subject to‚à´ùëëx‚Äãq‚Äã(x)=1,q‚Äã(x)‚â•0‚Äã‚àÄx.minimizedifferential-dùë•ùëùùë•ùëûùë•subject todifferential-dùë•ùëûùë•1missing-subexpressionùëûùë•0for-allùë•\begin{array}[]{ll}\textrm{minimize}&-\int dx\,p(x)\ln\left(q(x)\right),\\ \textrm{subject to}&\int dx\,q(x)=1,\\ &q(x)\geq 0\;\;\;\forall x.\end{array} (16)

5.1.1 Gaussian Densities

If qùëûq is log-concave in its parameters Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, the minimization problem (16) is a convex optimization problem. In particular, consider the case where X=‚Ñùnùëãsuperscript‚ÑùùëõX=\mathbb{R}^{n}, and qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} is a multivariate Gaussian density, with mean Œºùúá\mu and covariance Œ£Œ£\Sigma, parametrized as follows,

qŒº,Œ£‚Äã(x)=1(2‚ÄãœÄ)n/2‚Äã|Œ£|1/2‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àí(x‚àíŒº)T‚ÄãŒ£‚àí1‚Äã(x‚àíŒº)2),subscriptùëûùúáŒ£ùë•1superscript2ùúãùëõ2superscriptŒ£12superscriptùë•ùúáùëásuperscriptŒ£1ùë•ùúá2q_{\mu,\Sigma}(x)=\frac{1}{(2\pi)^{n/2}|\Sigma|^{1/2}}\exp\left(-\frac{(x-\mu)^{T}\Sigma^{-1}(x-\mu)}{2}\right),

then the optimal parameters are given by matching first and second moments of pùëùp and qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}.

Œº‚ãÜ=‚à´ùëëx‚Äãx‚Äãp‚Äã(x),Œ£‚ãÜ=‚à´ùëëx‚Äã(x‚àíŒº‚ãÜ)‚Äã(x‚àíŒº‚ãÜ)T‚Äãp‚Äã(x).superscriptùúá‚ãÜdifferential-dùë•ùë•ùëùùë•superscriptŒ£‚ãÜdifferential-dùë•ùë•superscriptùúá‚ãÜsuperscriptùë•superscriptùúá‚ãÜùëáùëùùë•\begin{array}[]{rcl}\mu^{\star}&=&\int dx\,x\,p(x),\\ \Sigma^{\star}&=&\int dx\,(x-\mu^{\star})(x-\mu^{\star})^{T}p(x).\end{array}

It is easy to generalize this to the case where X‚äÇ‚Ñùnùëãsuperscript‚ÑùùëõX\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}, by making a suitable modification to the definition of pùëùp. This is described in Sec.¬†5.2.1.

5.1.3 Mixture Models

The single Gaussian is a fairly restrictive class of models. Mixture models can significantly improve flexibility, but at the cost of convexity of the KL distance minimization problem. However, a plethora of techniques from supervized learning, in particular the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm, can be applied with minor modifications.

Suppose qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} is a mixture of MùëÄM Gaussians, that is, Œ∏=(Œº,Œ£,œï)ùúÉùúáŒ£italic-œï\theta=(\mu,\Sigma,\phi) where œïitalic-œï\phi is the mixing p.m.f, we can view the problem as one where a hidden variable zùëßz decides which mixture component each sample is drawn from. We then have the optimization problem

minimize¬†‚àí‚àëDp‚Äã(xi)h‚Äã(xi)‚Äãln‚Å°(qŒ∏‚Äã(xi,zi)).minimize¬†subscriptùê∑ùëùsuperscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ñésuperscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëûùúÉsuperscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëßùëñ\textrm{minimize }-\sum_{D}\displaystyle\frac{p(x^{i})}{h(x^{i})}\ln\left(q_{\theta}(x^{i},z^{i})\right).

Following the standard EM procedure, we multiply and divide the quantity inside the logarithm by some Qi‚Äã(zi)subscriptùëÑùëñsuperscriptùëßùëñQ_{i}(z^{i}), where QisubscriptùëÑùëñQ_{i} is a distribution over the possible values of zisuperscriptùëßùëñz^{i}. As before, let sisuperscriptùë†ùëñs^{i} be the likelihood ratio of the iùëñi‚Äôth sample.

minimize¬†‚àí‚àëDsi‚Äãln‚Å°(‚àëziQi‚Äã(zi)‚ÄãqŒ∏‚Äã(xi,zi)Qi‚Äã(zi))minimize¬†subscriptùê∑superscriptùë†ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùëßùëñsubscriptùëÑùëñsuperscriptùëßùëñsubscriptùëûùúÉsuperscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëßùëñsubscriptùëÑùëñsuperscriptùëßùëñ\textrm{minimize }-\sum_{D}\displaystyle s^{i}\ln\left(\sum_{z^{i}}Q_{i}(z^{i})\frac{q_{\theta}(x^{i},z^{i})}{Q_{i}(z^{i})}\right)

Then using Jensen‚Äôs inequality, we can take QisubscriptùëÑùëñQ_{i} outside the logarithm to get a lower bound. To make this lower bound tight, choose Qi‚Äã(zi)subscriptùëÑùëñsuperscriptùëßùëñQ_{i}(z^{i}) to be the constant p‚Äã(zi|xi)ùëùconditionalsuperscriptùëßùëñsuperscriptùë•ùëñp(z^{i}|x^{i}). Finally, differentiating with respect to Œºj,Œ£j‚àí1subscriptùúáùëósubscriptsuperscriptŒ£1ùëó\mu_{j},\Sigma^{-1}_{j} and œïjsubscriptitalic-œïùëó\phi_{j} gives us the EM-like algorithm:

E-step: For each i, setQi‚Äã(zi)=p‚Äã(zi|xi),that is,wji=qŒº,Œ£,œï‚Äã(zi=j|xi),j=1,‚Ä¶,M.M-step: SetŒºj=‚àëDwji‚Äãsi‚Äãxi‚àëDwji‚Äãsi,Œ£j=‚àëDwji‚Äãsi‚Äã(xi‚àíŒºj)‚Äã(xi‚àíŒºj)T‚àëDwji‚Äãsi,œïj=‚àëDwji‚Äãsi‚àëDsi,E-step: For each i, setsubscriptùëÑùëñsuperscriptùëßùëñùëùconditionalsuperscriptùëßùëñsuperscriptùë•ùëñthat is,subscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëóformulae-sequencesubscriptùëûùúáŒ£italic-œïsuperscriptùëßùëñconditionalùëósuperscriptùë•ùëñùëó1‚Ä¶ùëÄM-step: Setsubscriptùúáùëósubscriptùê∑subscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëósuperscriptùë†ùëñsuperscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùê∑subscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëósuperscriptùë†ùëñmissing-subexpressionsubscriptŒ£ùëósubscriptùê∑subscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëósuperscriptùë†ùëñsuperscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùúáùëósuperscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùúáùëóùëásubscriptùê∑subscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëósuperscriptùë†ùëñmissing-subexpressionsubscriptitalic-œïùëósubscriptùê∑subscriptsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëósuperscriptùë†ùëñsubscriptùê∑superscriptùë†ùëñ\begin{array}[]{lrcl}\textrm{E-step: For each i, set}&Q_{i}(z^{i})&=&p(z^{i}|x^{i}),\\ \hskip 36.135pt\textrm{that is,}&w^{i}_{j}&=&q_{\mu,\Sigma,\phi}(z^{i}=j|x^{i}),\;\;\;j=1,\ldots,M.\\ \textrm{M-step: Set}&\mu_{j}&=&\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{D}w^{i}_{j}\displaystyle s^{i}\,x^{i}}{\sum_{D}w^{i}_{j}\displaystyle s^{i}},\\ &\Sigma_{j}&=&\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{D}w^{i}_{j}\displaystyle s^{i}\,(x^{i}-\mu_{j})(x^{i}-\mu_{j})^{T}}{\sum_{D}w^{i}_{j}\displaystyle s^{i}},\\ &\phi_{j}&=&\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{D}w^{i}_{j}\displaystyle s^{i}}{\sum_{D}\displaystyle s^{i}},\\ \end{array}

Since this is a nonconvex problem, one typically runs the algorithm multiple times with random initializations of the parameters.

5.2 Implementation Details

In this section we describe the implementation details of an iterative immediate-sampling PC algorithm that uses the Gaussian mixture models described in the previous section to minimize p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq KL distance to a Boltzmann target parametrized by Œ≤ùõΩ\beta. We also describe the modification of a variety of techniques from parmetric learning that significantly improve performance of this algorithm. An overview of the procedure is presented in Algorithm¬†1.

5.2.4 Cross-validation to Schedule Œ≤ùõΩ\beta

In more complex problems, it may be difficult to find a good value for the Œ≤ùõΩ\beta update ratio kŒ≤subscriptùëòùõΩk_{\beta}. However, we note that the objective KL(pŒ≤‚à•qŒ∏)conditionalsuperscriptùëùùõΩsubscriptùëûùúÉ(p^{\beta}\|q_{\theta}) can be viewed as a regularized version of the original objective, ùîºqŒ∏‚Äã[G‚Äã(x)]subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉdelimited-[]ùê∫ùë•\mathbb{E}_{q_{\theta}}[G(x)]. Therefore, we use the standard PL technique of cross-validation to pick the regularization parameter Œ≤ùõΩ\beta from some set {Œ≤}ùõΩ\{\beta\}. At each iteration, we partition the data set Dùê∑D into training and test data sets DTsubscriptùê∑ùëáD_{T} and DVsubscriptùê∑ùëâD_{V}. Next, we test the associated qŒ∏‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œ≤)subscriptùëûsuperscriptùúÉ‚ãÜùõΩq_{\theta^{\star}(\beta)} on the test data DVsubscriptùê∑ùëâD_{V} using the following performance measure.

Finally, we set Œ≤‚ãÜ=arg‚Å°minŒ≤‚àà{Œ≤}‚Å°g^‚Äã(Œ∏‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œ≤))superscriptùõΩ‚ãÜsubscriptùõΩùõΩ^ùëîsuperscriptùúÉ‚ãÜùõΩ\beta^{\star}=\arg\min_{\beta\in\{\beta\}}\widehat{g}(\theta^{\star}(\beta)), and compute Œ∏‚ãÜ‚Äã(Œ≤‚ãÜ)superscriptùúÉ‚ãÜsuperscriptùõΩ‚ãÜ\theta^{\star}(\beta^{\star}) using all the data Dùê∑D. Note that the whole cross-validation procedure is carried out without any more calls to the oracle ùí¢ùí¢\mathscr{G}.
