This poor fit is shown in Fig.¬†4, where we show a least-squares fit to both Œ≤ùõΩ\beta and log‚Å°(Œ≤)ùõΩ\log(\beta). In the fit to log‚Å°(Œ≤)ùõΩ\log(\beta) the final Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is off by over 100%, and in the fit to Œ≤ùõΩ\beta, the initial Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is off by several orders of magnitude.

We then compare the performance of cross-validation to that of PC algorithm using the fixed update rule derived from the best least-squares fit to log‚Å°(Œ≤)ùõΩ\log(\beta). From a comparison over 50 runs, we see that using this best-fit update rule performs extremely poorly - cross-validation yields an improvement in final ùîºqŒ∏‚ÄãG‚Äã(x)subscriptùîºsubscriptùëûùúÉùê∫ùë•\mathbb{E}_{q_{\theta}}G(x) by over an order of magnitude, as shown in Fig.¬†5.

5.2.5 Bagging

While regularization is a method to decrease bias, bagging is a well-known variance-reducing technique. Bagging is easily incorporated in our algorithm. Suppose, at some stage in the algorithm, we have NùëÅN samples (xi,gi)superscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëîùëñ(x^{i},g^{i}), we resample our existing data set exactly NùëÅN times with replacement. This gives us a different set of data set D‚Ä≤superscriptùê∑‚Ä≤D^{\prime}, which also contains some duplicates. We compute optimal parameters Œ∏‚ãÜ‚Äã(D‚Ä≤)superscriptùúÉ‚ãÜsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤\theta^{\star}(D^{\prime}). We repeat this resampling process kbsubscriptùëòùëèk_{b} times and uniformly average the resulting optimal densities qŒ∏‚ãÜ‚Äã(Dk‚Ä≤),k=1,‚Ä¶,kbformulae-sequencesubscriptùëûsuperscriptùúÉ‚ãÜsubscriptsuperscriptùê∑‚Ä≤ùëòùëò1‚Ä¶subscriptùëòùëèq_{\theta^{\star}(D^{\prime}_{k})},k=1,\ldots,k_{b}.

We demonstrate this procedure, using the Rosenbrock function and a single Gaussian qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}. In this experiment, we also demonstrate the ability of PC to handle non-deterministic oracles by adding uniform random noise to every function evaluation, that is, (g‚à£x,G)‚àºùí∞‚Äã[‚àí0.25,0.25]similar-toconditionalùëîùë•ùê∫ùí∞0.250.25(g\mid x,G)\sim\mathcal{U}[-0.25,0.25]. For this experiment, Nj=20,kb=5formulae-sequencesubscriptùëÅùëó20subscriptùëòùëè5N_{j}=20,k_{b}=5. The Œ≤ùõΩ\beta update is performed using the same cross-validation algorithm described above. Fig.¬†6 shows the results of 50 runs of the PC algorithm with and without bagging.

We see that bagging finds better solutions, and moreover, it reduces the variance between runs. Note that the way we use bagging, we are only assured of improved variance for a single MC estimation at a given Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, and not over the whole MCO process of searching over Œ∏ùúÉ\theta.

5.2.6 Cross-validation for Regularization and Model Selection

In many problems like the Rosenbrock, a single Gaussian is a poor fit to pŒ≤superscriptùëùùõΩp^{\beta} for many values of Œ≤ùõΩ\beta. In these cases, we can use a mixture of Gaussians to obtain a better fit to pŒ≤superscriptùëùùõΩp^{\beta}. We now describe the use of cross-validation to pick the number of components in the mixture model. We use an algorithm very similar to the one described for regularization. In these experiments, we use a greedy algorithm to search over the joint space of Œ≤ùõΩ\beta and models:

  1. 1.

    We first pick the regularization parameter Œ≤ùõΩ\beta, using Algorithm¬†2.

  2. 2.

    For that Œ≤ùõΩ\beta, we use Algorithm¬†3 to pick the number of mixture components.

For this experiment, the details are the same as the preceding section, but without bagging. The set of models {{œï}}italic-œï\{\{\phi\}\} is the set of Gaussian mixtures with one, two or three mixing components. Fig.¬†7 shows the variation of ùîºq‚Äã(G)subscriptùîºùëûùê∫\mathbb{E}_{q}(G) vs. iteration.

The mixture model is much quicker to yield lower expected G, because the Boltzmann at many values of Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is better approximated by a mixture of Gaussians. However, note that the mixture models performs poorly towards the end of the run. The reason for this is as follows: No shape regularization was used during the EM procedure. This means that the algorithm often samples from nearly degenerate Gaussians. These ‚Äòstrange‚Äô sample sets hurt the subsequent performance of importance sampling, and hence of the associated MCO problem. This can be alleviated by using some form of shape regularization in the EM algorithm.

6 Fit-based Monte Carlo

Thus far, we have not exploited the locations of the samples in constructing esimates. In this section, we discuss the incorporation of sample locations to improve both MC and MCO.

6.1 Fit-based MC Estimation of Integrals

We first consider MC estimation of an integral, presented at the beginning of Sec.¬†2.3. Recall from that discussion, that to accord with MCO notation, we write the integral to be estimated as ‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)=‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)‚Ñíitalic-œïdifferential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)=\int dw\;U(w,\phi) for some fixed œïitalic-œï\phi. In this notation the sampling of vùë£v provides a sample set {(wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï)):i=1,‚Ä¶‚ÄãN)delimited-{):superscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œïùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëÅ\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)):i=1,\ldots N). The associated sum ‚Ñí^{(wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï))}‚â°‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï)subscript^‚Ñísuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œï^‚Ñíitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}}\equiv{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) then serves as our estimate of the integral ‚Ñí‚â°‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)‚Ñí‚Ñíitalic-œï{\mathscr{L}}\equiv{\mathscr{L}}(\phi).

In forming the estimate ‚Ñí^{(wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï))}subscript^‚Ñísuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}} we do not exploit the relationships between the locations of the sample points and the associated values of the integrand. Indeed, since those locations {wisuperscriptùë§ùëñw^{i}} do not appear directly in that estimate, ‚Ñí^{(wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï))}subscript^‚Ñísuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}} is unchanged even if those locations changed in such a way that the values {risuperscriptùëüùëñr^{i}} stayed the same.

The idea behind fit-based (FB) Monte Carlo is to leverage the location data to replace ‚Ñí^{(wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï))}subscript^‚Ñísuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}} with a more accurate estimate of ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathscr{L}. The most straightforward FB MC treats the sample pairs {(wi,U(wi,œï)):i=1,‚Ä¶N)(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)):i=1,\ldots N)} as a training set for a supervised-learning algorithm. Running such an algorithm produces a fit U~(.,œï){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi) taking wùë§w‚Äôs into ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}. This fit is an estimate of the actual oracle U(,œï)U(,\phi), and this fit defines an estimate for the full integral,

‚Ñí~{wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï)}‚â°‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU~‚Äã(w,œï)subscript~‚Ñísuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œïdifferential-dùë§~ùëàùë§italic-œï\displaystyle{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)\}}\equiv\int dw\;{\tilde{U}}(w,\phi) (19)

We will sometimes omit the subscript and just write ‚Ñí~‚Äã(œï)~‚Ñíitalic-œï{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) or even just ‚Ñí~~‚Ñí{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}. In this most straightforward version of FB MC, we use ‚Ñí~~‚Ñí{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}} as our estimate of ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathscr{L} rather than ‚Ñí^^‚Ñí{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}.

In some circumstances one can evaluate ‚Ñí~~‚Ñí{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}} in closed form. A recent paper reviewing some work on how to do this with Gaussian processes is given by¬†Rasmussen and Gharamani (2003). In other circumstances one can form low-order approximations to ‚Ñí‚Ñí{\mathscr{L}}, for example using Laplace approximations¬†(see Robert and Casella, 2004). Alternatively, conventional deterministic grid-based approximation of the integral ‚Ñí‚Ñí{\mathscr{L}} can be cast as a degenerate version of closed-form fit-based estimation131313To see this, modify the MC process to be sampling without replacement. Choose the proposal distribution vùë£v for this process to be a sum of delta functions. The centers of those delta functions give the points on a regular grid of points in the space of allowed xùë•x‚Äôs. Have the number of samples equal the number of such grid points. Finally, have our fit to the samples, U~(.,œï){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi), be a sum of step-wise constant functions, going through the sample points. The closed form integral of that fit given by Eq.¬†19 is just the Reimann approximation to the original integral, ‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)differential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï\int dw\;U(w,\phi). of ‚Ñí‚Ñí{\mathscr{L}}.

More generally, one can form an approximation to the integral ‚Ñí~‚Äã(œï)~‚Ñíitalic-œï{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) by MC sampling of U~(.,œï){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi). Generating these fictitious samples of U~(.,œï)\tilde{U}(.,\phi) does not incur the expense of calling the actual oracle U(.,œï)U(.,\phi). So, in this approach, we run MC twice. The first time, we generate the factual samples {(wi,U(wi,œï)):i=1,‚Ä¶N)(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)):i=1,\ldots N)}. Given those samples, we form the fit to them, U~(.,œï)\tilde{U}(.,\phi). We then run a second MC process using the fictitious oracle U~(.,œï)\tilde{U}(.,\phi).

Note that in all of these approaches, the original sampling distribution vùë£v does not directly arise, that is, the values {v‚Äã(wi)ùë£superscriptùë§ùëñv(w^{i})} do not arise. In particular, if one were to change those values without changing the factual sample locations {wi}superscriptùë§ùëñ\{w^{i}\}, then the estimate ‚Ñí~{(wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï))}subscript~‚Ñísuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œï{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}} would not change. Of course, a different vùë£v would result in a different sample set, and thereby a different estimate, but given a sample set, the sampling distribution is immaterial. This is typically the case with FB MC estimators, and it contrasts with the estimator ‚Ñí^{(wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï))}subscript^‚Ñísuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}}, which would change if vùë£v were changed without changing the factual sample locations.

Note also that the factual samples underlying the fit U~(.,œï){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi) are exact samples of the factual oracle, U(.,œï)U(.,\phi). In contrast, since in general U~(.,œï)‚â†U(.,œï){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi)\neq U(.,\phi), the fictitious samples will be erroneous, if viewed as samples of U(.,œï)U(.,\phi). Since we are ultimately concerned with an integral of U(.,œï)U(.,\phi), this suggests that the fictitious samples should be weighted less than the factual samples. This might be the case even if one had infinitely many fictitious samples. In fact, even if one could evaluate ‚Ñí~~‚Ñí{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}} in closed form, it might make sense not to use it directly as our final estimate of ‚Ñí‚Ñí{\mathscr{L}}. Instead, combining it with the importance-sampling estimate ‚Ñí^^‚Ñí{\hat{\mathscr{L}}} might improve the estimate.

6.2 Bayesian Fit-based MCO

We now extend the discussion to MCO by allowing œïitalic-œï\phi to vary. As with the case of FB MC estimation of an integral, the most straightforward version of FB MCO uses ‚Ñí~‚Äã(œï)~‚Ñíitalic-œï{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) rather than ‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï)^‚Ñíitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) as our estimate of ‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)‚Ñíitalic-œï{\mathscr{L}}(\phi). This means that we use argmin[‚Ñí~(œï)]œï{}_{\phi}[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)] rather than argmin[‚Ñí^(œï)]œï{}_{\phi}[{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)] as our estimate of the œïitalic-œï\phi optimizing ‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)‚Ñíitalic-œï{\mathscr{L}}(\phi).

‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï)^‚Ñíitalic-œï{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is a sum, whereas ‚Ñí~‚Äã(œï)~‚Ñíitalic-œï{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is an integral. This means that different algorithms are required to find the œïitalic-œï\phi optimizing them. Indeed, optimizing ‚Ñí~‚Äã(œï)~‚Ñíitalic-œï{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is formally the same type of problem as optimizing ‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)‚Ñíitalic-œï{\mathscr{L}}(\phi); both functions of œïitalic-œï\phi are parametrized integrals over wùë§w. So if needed, we can use PLMCO techniques to optimize ‚Ñí~‚Äã(œï)~‚Ñíitalic-œï{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi). Again, as with MC, the integrand of ‚Ñí~‚Äã(œï)~‚Ñíitalic-œï{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is not the factual oracle. So, minimizing ‚Ñí~‚Äã(œï)~‚Ñíitalic-œï{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) using PLMCO sampling techniques will not require making additional calls to the factual oracle.

Consider a Bayesian approach to forming the fit. Our problem is to solve the MCO problem (P2), given that the factual oracle UùëàU is not known, and we only can generate samples of UùëàU. Adopting a fully Bayesian perspective, since UùëàU is not known, we must treat it as a random variable. So we have a posterior distribution over all possible oracles, reflecting all the data we have concerning the factual oracle. We then use that posterior to try to solve (P2).

Say that in the usual way that our data contains the wùë§w‚Äôs and the associated functions U(w,.)U(w,.) of a sample set that was generated by importance sampling UùëàU (see Sec.¬†2). More generally, we may have additional data, for instance, the gradients of UùëàU at the sample points. For simplicity though, we restrict attention to the case where the provided information is only the sample set of functions, {wi,ri(.)}\{w^{i},r^{i}(.)\}, together with vùë£v.

We will use Dùê∑D to refer to a sample set for MC or MCO, and for immediate sampling in particular. So we write our posterior over oracles141414Practically, when running a computer experiment, UùëàU is the actual oracle generating Dùê∑D according to a likelihood P(D‚à£UP(D\mid U). On the other hand, the posterior P‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑P(U_{c}\mid D) reflects both that likelihood and a prior P‚Äã(Uc)ùëÉsubscriptùëàùëêP(U_{c}) assumed by the algorithm. So, UcsubscriptùëàùëêU_{c} is a random variable, whereas UùëàU refers to the single true factual oracle. as P‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑P(U_{c}\mid D). Using this notation, the goal in Bayesian FB MCO is to exploit P‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑P(U_{c}\mid D) to improve our estimate of the œïitalic-œï\phi that minimizes ‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)differential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï\int dw\;U(w,\phi).

How should we use P‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑P({U_{c}}\mid D) to estimate the solution to (P2)? Bayesian decision theory tells us to minimize posterior expected loss, ‚à´ùëëUc‚ÄãP‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)‚ÄãL‚Äã(œï,Uc)differential-dsubscriptùëàùëêùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑ùêøitalic-œïsubscriptùëàùëê\int d{U_{c}}\;P({U_{c}}\mid D)L(\phi,{U_{c}}). Given the loss function of Eq.¬†4, that means we wish to solve

(P6):¬†‚Äãminœï‚Äã‚à´ùëëUc‚ÄãP‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)‚ÄãL‚Äã(œï,Uc)(P6):¬†subscriptitalic-œïdifferential-dsubscriptùëàùëêùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑ùêøitalic-œïsubscriptùëàùëê\displaystyle\textrm{(P6): }\min_{\phi}\int d{U_{c}}\;P({U_{c}}\mid D)L(\phi,{U_{c}}) =\displaystyle= minœï‚Äã‚à´ùëëwc‚ÄãùëëUc‚ÄãP‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)‚ÄãUc‚Äã(wc,œï).subscriptitalic-œïdifferential-dsubscriptùë§ùëêdifferential-dsubscriptùëàùëêùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑subscriptùëàùëêsubscriptùë§ùëêitalic-œï\displaystyle\min_{\phi}\int dw_{c}d{U_{c}}\;P({U_{c}}\mid D){U_{c}}(w_{c},\phi).

To avoid confusion, the variable of integration is written as wcsubscriptùë§ùëêw_{c}, to distinguish it from wùë§w‚Äôs in the integral ‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)differential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï\int dw\;U(w,\phi). Sometimes we may be able to solve (P6) in closed form, even when we cannot solve (P2) in closed form. Performing the integral over Ucsubscriptùëàùëê{U_{c}} may simplify the remaining integral over wcsubscriptùë§ùëêw_{c}. More generally, we can address (P6) using MCO techniques, and in particular using PLMCO.151515To see that explicitly, rewrite the integral in (P2) as ‚à´ùëëz‚ÄãV‚Äã(z,œï)differential-dùëßùëâùëßitalic-œï\int dz\;V(z,\phi), and identify values of zùëßz with pairs (wc,Uc)subscriptùë§ùëêsubscriptùëàùëê(w_{c},{U_{c}}), while taking V‚Äã(z,œï)=V‚Äã(wc,Uc,œï)=P‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)‚ÄãUc‚Äã(wc,œï)ùëâùëßitalic-œïùëâsubscriptùë§ùëêsubscriptùëàùëêitalic-œïùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑subscriptùëàùëêsubscriptùë§ùëêitalic-œïV(z,\phi)=V(w_{c},{U_{c}},\phi)=P({U_{c}}\mid D){U_{c}}(w_{c},\phi).

To solve (P6) with PLMCO one generates fictitious samples by sampling one distribution over Ucsubscriptùëàùëê{U_{c}}‚Äôs and one over wcsubscriptùë§ùëêw_{c}‚Äôs. This MC process does not involve calls to the actual oracle UùëàU, but samples a new distribution over Ucsubscriptùëàùëê{U_{c}}‚Äôs, to generate counter-factual Ucsubscriptùëàùëê{U_{c}}‚Äôs, and then samples those Ucsubscriptùëàùëê{U_{c}}‚Äôs.

6.3 Example: Fit-based Immediate Sampling

To illustrate the foregoing we consider the variant of MCO given by immediate sampling with a noise-free oracle. In the simple version of MCO considered just above, the estimate we make for œïitalic-œï\phi has no effect on what points are chosen for any future calls we might make to the oracle. For simplicity, we restrict attention to the analogous formulation of immediate sampling. Using immediate sampling terminology, this means that we only consider the issue of how best to estimate Œ∏ùúÉ\theta after the immediate sampling algorithm has exhausted all its calls to the oracle. We do not consider the more general active learning issue, of how best to estimate Œ∏ùúÉ\theta when this estimate will be affect further calls to the oracle. However see Sec.¬†6.6 below.

Sometimes, these integrals also can be evaluated algebraically, giving closed form sample functions of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. Next, say that we have a Gaussian process prior over oracles, P‚Äã(Gc)ùëÉsubscriptùê∫ùëêP(G_{c})¬†(Rasmussen and Williams, 2006), with a Gaussian covariance kernel. In practice, this may make the computation be ill-behaved numerically. Typically such problems are addressed modeling the fictitious oracles as though the values they returned had a small amount of Gaussian noise added. In other situations, while we cannot evaluate them exactly, the integrals TD,{xci}‚Äã(Œ∏)subscriptùëáùê∑superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëêùëñùúÉT_{D,\{x_{c}^{i}\}}(\theta) can be accurately approximated algebraically. In either of these cases, there is no need to sample HùêªH; samples of hcsubscript‚Ñéùëêh_{c} suffice. So for either case we can write ‚Ñ±~D‚Äã(Œ∏)‚âà‚Ñ±~^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript~‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉsubscript^~‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta)\approx{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta).191919As a practical issue, we may want to divide the sum in Eq.¬†26 by the empirical average ‚àëi=1NTP‚Äã(Gci‚à£D)hc‚Äã(xci)superscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëáùëÉconditionalsubscriptsuperscriptùê∫ùëñùëêùê∑subscript‚Ñéùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëêùëñ\sum_{i=1}^{N_{T}}\frac{P(G^{i}_{c}\mid D)}{h_{c}(x_{c}^{i})}. In both cases, under naive MCO, we search for the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta that minimizes ‚Ñ±~^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^~‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta). We then use that Œ∏ùúÉ\theta as our estimate for the solution to (P6). More generally, rather than use naive MCO we can exploit our sample functions with PLMCO. For example, rather than minimizing ‚Ñ±~^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^~‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta), we could minimize a sum of {‚Ñ±~D(Œ∏){\{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta) and a regularization penalty term.

However we arrive at our (estimated) optimal qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}, most simplistically, we can update h‚Ñéh to equal that new qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}. In a more sophisticated approach, we could set h‚Ñéh from the sample functions using active learning (see Sec.¬†6.6 below). Once we have that new h‚Ñéh we can form samples of it to generate new factual sample locations xùë•x. These in turn are fed to the factual oracle Gùê∫G to augment our data set Dùê∑D. Then the process repeats.

Note that unlike with non-FB immediate sampling, with FB immediate sampling we need to evaluate P‚Äã(Gc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùëêùê∑P({G_{c}}\mid D) (or sample it, if we choose to have H‚Äã(Gc)‚âúP‚Äã(Gc‚à£D)‚âúùêªsubscriptùê∫ùëêùëÉconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùëêùê∑H({G_{c}})\triangleq P({G_{c}}\mid D)). This may be non-trivial. On the other hand, that very same distribution P‚Äã(Gc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùëêùê∑P({G_{c}}\mid D) that may cause difficulty also gives the major advantage of the fit-based approach; it allows any insights we have into how to fit a curve Gcsubscriptùê∫ùëê{G_{c}} to the data points Dùê∑D to be exploited.

6.4 Exploiting FB Immediate Sampling

To illustrate how fitting might improve immediate sampling, consider the case where ‚Ñ±G‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫subscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) is q‚Äãpùëûùëùqp KL distance. Say that G‚Äã(x)ùê∫ùë•G(x) is a high-dimensional convex paraboloid inside a hypercube, and zero outside of that hypercube. Suppose as well that we have a single factual sampling distribution h‚Ñéh, which is concentrated on one side of the paraboloid. For example, if the peak of the paraboloid is at the origin, h‚Ñéh might be a Gaussian (masked by the hypercube) whose mean lies several sigmas away from the origin.

To start, consider importance sampling MC estimation of the integral ‚Ñ±G‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫subscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) for one particular Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, without any concern about choosing among Œ∏ùúÉ\theta‚Äôs. Say that the factual sample Dùê∑D isn‚Äôt too large. Then it is likely that no elements of Dùê∑D are in regions where Gùê∫G reaches its lowest values. For such a Dùê∑D, the associated factual estimate

‚Ñ±^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ\displaystyle{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta) ‚âú‚âú\displaystyle\triangleq ‚àëirhi‚Äã(xi,Œ∏)Nsubscriptùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùëüùëñ‚Ñésuperscriptùë•ùëñùúÉùëÅ\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{i}r^{i}_{h}(x^{i},\theta)}{N} (27)

is larger than the actual value, ‚Ñ±G‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫subscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) (cf. Eq.¬†14). So straightforward importance-sampling integral estimation is likely to be badly off.202020Since importance sampling is unbiased, this means its variance is likely to be large.

Intuitively, the problem is that as far as the factual estimate ‚Ñ±^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta) is concerned, Gùê∫G could just as well be a sum of delta functions centered at the xùë•x‚Äôs in Dùê∑D, with low associated oracle sample values, as a paraboloid. If Gùê∫G were in fact such a sum, then ‚Ñ±^Dsubscript^‚Ñ±ùê∑{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{D} would be correct. However by looking at the (x,G‚Äã(x))ùë•ùê∫ùë•(x,G(x)) pairs in Dùê∑D, all of which lie on the same paraboloid, such an inference of Gùê∫G appears quite unreasonable. It makes sense to instead infer that Gùê∫G is a paraboloid.

Fitting is a way to formalize (and exploit) such Dùê∑D-based insights. As an example, consider using a Bayesian PL algorithm to do the fitting. Typical choices for the prior P‚Äã(Gc)ùëÉsubscriptùê∫ùëêP({G_{c}}) used in PL would result in a posterior P‚Äã(Gc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùëêùê∑P({G_{c}}\mid{D}) that would be far more tightly concentrated about the actual Gùê∫G‚Äôs paraboloid shape than about the sum of delta functions. Fitting would automatically reflect this, and thereby produce a better estimate of ‚Ñ±G‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(\theta) than ‚Ñ±^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta).212121It might be objected that in a different problem Gùê∫G actually would be the sum of delta functions, not the paraboloid. In that case the FB estimate is the one that would be in error. However this possibility is exactly what the prior P‚Äã(Gc)ùëÉsubscriptùê∫ùëêP({G_{c}}) addresses; if in fact you have reason to believe that a Gùê∫G that is a sum of delta functions is a priori just as likely as a paraboloid Gùê∫G, then that should be reflected in P‚Äã(Gc)ùëÉsubscriptùê∫ùëêP({G_{c}}). Doing so would in turn make the FB estimate more closely track the non-FB estimate.

Now we aren‚Äôt directly concerned with the accuracy of our estimate ‚Ñ±G‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫subscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) for any single Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. We aren‚Äôt even concerned with the overall accuracy of that estimate for a set of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta‚Äôs. Rather we are concerned with the accuracy of the ranking of the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta‚Äôs given by those estimates. For example, consider naive MCO, under which we choose the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta minimizing ‚Ñ±~D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript~‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta). Even if all of our estimates (one for each Œ∏ùúÉ\theta) were far from the associated actual values, if their signed errors were identical, the naive MCO would perform perfectly.

In other words, ultimately we are interested in correlations between errors of our estimates of ‚Ñ±G‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫subscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) for different Œ∏ùúÉ\theta‚Äôs. (See Sec.¬†2.3.) Nonetheless, we might expect that if we tend to have large error in our estimates of ‚Ñ±G‚Äã(qŒ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫subscriptùëûùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) for the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta‚Äôs, then everything else being equal, we would be likely to have large error in the associated estimate of an optimal Œ∏ùúÉ\theta.

In Sec.¬†4.5 we exploited the equivalence between PL and MCO to improve upon naive MCO. However the parameter in MCO doesn‚Äôt specify a functional fit to a data set. Accordingly, the incorporation of PL into MCO considered in Sec.¬†4.5 doesn‚Äôt involve fitting a function to Dùê∑D. This is why those PLMCO techniques don‚Äôt address the issue raised in this example; fitting does that. So in full FB MCO, we may use PL in two separate parts of the algorithm, both to form the fit to Dùê∑D, and then to use those fits to choose among the Œ∏ùúÉ\theta‚Äôs.

6.5 Statistical Analysis of FB MC

Before analyzing expected performance of FB MCO, we start with the simpler case of FB MC introduced at the beginning of this section. For simplicity we assume that the integral ‚Ñí~Dsubscript~‚Ñíùê∑{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} can be calculated exactly for any Dùê∑D, so that no fictitious samples arise.

As discussed in Sec.¬†2.3, two important properties of an MC estimator of an integral ‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)=‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)‚Ñíitalic-œïdifferential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)=\int dw\;U(w,\phi) are the sample bias and the sample variance of that estimator. Together, these give the expected loss of the estimator under a quadratic loss function, conditioned on a fixed oracle U(.,œï)U(.,\phi).

This is just as true for a Bayesian fitting algorithm as for any other. For quadratic loss, for sample set D‚â°{wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï)}ùê∑superscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œïD\equiv\{w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)\}, the Bayesian FB MC prediction for ‚Ñí‚Ñí{\mathscr{L}} is the posterior mean,

‚Ñí~Dsubscript~‚Ñíùê∑\displaystyle{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} =\displaystyle= ‚à´dw‚Ä≤dUc(.,œï)Uc(w‚Ä≤,œï)P(Uc(.,œï)‚à£D).\displaystyle\int d{w}^{\prime}\;dU_{c}(.,\phi)\;U_{c}({w}^{\prime},\phi)P(U_{c}(.,\phi)\mid D). (28)

Accordingly, the expected quadratic loss of Bayesian FBMC is

‚à´dDP(D‚à£v,U(.,œï))[‚Ñí‚àí‚Ñí~D]2=\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\int dD\;P(D\mid v,U(.,\phi))[{\mathscr{L}}-{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D}]^{2}\;\;=
‚à´dw1‚Ä¶dwN‚àèi=1Nv(wi)[‚à´dw‚Ä≤U(w‚Ä≤,œï)‚àí‚à´dw‚Ä≤dUc(,œï)Uc(w‚Ä≤,œï)P(Uc(.,œï)‚à£D)]2\displaystyle\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})[\int d{w}^{\prime}\;U({w}^{\prime},\phi)\;-\;\int d{w}^{\prime}\;dU_{c}(,\phi)\;U_{c}({w}^{\prime},\phi)P(U_{c}(.,\phi)\mid D)]^{2} (29)

where vùë£v is the proposal distribution that is IID sampled NùëÅ{N} times to generate the sample set.

In the usual way one can re-express this expected quadratic loss using a bias-variance decomposition. Whereas a conventional importance sample estimator of ‚à´ùëëw‚ÄãU‚Äã(w,œï)differential-dùë§ùëàùë§italic-œï\int d{w}\;U(w,\phi) is unbiased, the Bayesian estimator is biased in general; typically

‚à´dDP(D‚à£v,U(.,œï))‚Ñí~D\displaystyle\int dD\;P(D\mid v,U(.,\phi))\;{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} ‚â†\displaystyle\neq ‚Ñí.‚Ñí\displaystyle{\mathscr{L}}. (30)

This bias is a general characteristic of Bayesian estimators. Furthermore, for some functions U(.,œï)U(.,\phi), the Bayesian estimator will both be biased (unlike the factual sample estimator) and have higher variance than the factual sample estimator. So for those U(.,œï)U(.,\phi), the Bayesian estimator has worse bias plus variance.

In conventional importance sampling estimation of an integral, the sampling distribution vùë£v is used twice. First it is used to form the sample set. Then, when the sample set has been formed, vùë£v is used again, to set the denominator values in the ratios giving the MC estimate of the integral (cf. Sec.¬†2.2). In contrast, Bayesian FB MC doesn‚Äôt care what vùë£v is. P(Uc(.,œï)‚à£D)P(U_{c}(.,\phi)\mid D) is independent of the values v‚Äã(wi)ùë£superscriptùë§ùëñv({w}^{i}). As mentioned at the beginning of this section, this is a typical feature of FB MC estimators.

This feature does not mean that the sampling distribution is immaterial in FB MC however. Even though it does not arise in making the estimate, as Eq.¬†29 shows, vùë£v helps determine what the expected loss will be. Indeed, in principle at least, Eq.¬†29 can be used to guide the choice of the sampling distribution for Bayesian FB MC. It can even be used this way dynamically, at a midpoint of the sampling process, when one already has some samples of U(.,œï)U(.,\phi). Such a procedure for using Eq.¬†29 to set vùë£v dynamically amounts to what is called ‚Äòactive learning‚Äô in the PL literature¬†(see Freund et¬†al., 1997; Dasgupta and Kalai, 2005).

We now generalize the foregoing to the case of a non-quadratic loss function LùêøL. The Bayesian estimator produces the estimate

‚Ñí~Dsubscript~‚Ñíùê∑\displaystyle{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} ‚âú‚âú\displaystyle\triangleq argminœÅ‚àà‚Ñù[‚à´dUc(.,œï)P(Uc(.,œï)‚à£D)L[‚Ñí~D,‚ÑíUc]]\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{\rho\in{\mathbb{R}}}[\int dU_{c}(.,\phi)\;P(U_{c}(.,\phi)\mid D)L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D},\;\;{\mathscr{L}}_{U_{c}}]] (31)

Given that the factual oracle is U(.,œï)U(.,\phi), the expected loss with that Bayesian estimator is

‚à´ùëëw1‚Äã‚Ä¶‚ÄãùëëwN‚Äã‚àèi=1Nv‚Äã(wi)‚ÄãL‚Äã[‚Ñí~{wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï)},‚à´ùëëw‚Ä≤‚ÄãU‚Äã(w‚Ä≤,œï)].differential-dsuperscriptùë§1‚Ä¶differential-dsuperscriptùë§ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÅùë£superscriptùë§ùëñùêøsubscript~‚Ñísuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œïdifferential-dsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤ùëàsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤italic-œï\displaystyle\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{{w}^{i},U({w}^{i},\phi)\}},\;\;\int d{w}^{\prime}\;U({w}^{\prime},\phi)]. (32)

The expected loss in Eq.¬†32 is an average over data with the oracle held fixed. This contrasts with the analogous quantity typically considered in Bayesian analysis, which is an average over oracles with the data held fixed. That quantity is the posterior expected loss,

‚à´dU(.,œï)P(U(.,œï)‚à£D)L[‚Ñí~D,‚ÑíU(œï)]\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)P(U(.,\phi)\mid D)L[{{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D},\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)] (33)

In general, different U(.,œï)U(.,\phi)‚Äôs will give different risks for the same estimator. So we can adapt any measure concerning loss in which U(.,œï)U(.,\phi) varies, to concern risk instead. In particular, the posterior expected risk is

‚à´dU(.,œï)P(U(.,œï)‚à£D){L[‚Ñí~D,‚ÑíU(œï)]‚àíminœÅ‚àà‚Ñù[L[œÅ,‚ÑíU(œï)]]}.\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)P(U(.,\phi)\mid D)\;\{L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D},{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)]\;-\;{\mbox{min}}_{\rho\in{\mathbb{R}}}[L[\rho,{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)]]\}. (34)

Often the lower bound on loss is always 0, so that minœÅ‚àà‚Ñù[L[œÅ,‚ÑíU(œï)]]=0‚àÄU(.,œï){\mbox{min}}_{\rho\in{\mathbb{R}}}[L[\rho,{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)]]=0\;\forall\;U(.,\phi). In this case posterior expected risk just equals posterior expected loss.

We can combine the non-Bayesian and Bayesian analyses, involving expected loss and posterior expected loss respectively. To do this we consider the prior-averaged expected loss, given by

‚à´dU(.,œï)P(U(.,œï))‚à´dw1‚Ä¶dwN‚àèi=1Nv(wi)L[‚Ñí~{(wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï))},‚à´dw‚Ä≤U(w‚Ä≤,œï)].\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)\;P(U(.,\phi))\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{({w}^{i},U({w}^{i},\phi))\}},\;\int d{w}^{\prime}\;U({w}^{\prime},\phi)]. (35)

where P(U(.,œï))P(U(.,\phi)) is a prior distribution over oracles.

Note that the prior-averaged expected loss is an average over both oracles and sample sets. It reflects the following experimental test of our FB MCO algorithm: Multiple times a factual oracle U(.,œï)U(.,\phi) is generated by sampling P(U(.,œï))P(U(.,\phi)). For each such U(.,œï)U(.,\phi), many times a factual sample set Dùê∑D is generated by sampling the likelihood P(D‚à£U(.,œï),v)P(D\mid U(.,\phi),v). That Dùê∑D is then used by the FMCO algorithm to calculate ‚ÑíDsubscript‚Ñíùê∑{\mathscr{L}}_{D}. In performing that calculation, the algorithm assumes the same likelihood as was used to generate Dùê∑D, but its prior P(Uc(.,œï))P(U_{c}(.,\phi)) may not be the same function of Uc(.,œï)U_{c}(.,\phi) as P(U(.,œï))P(U(.,\phi)) is of U(.,œï)U(.,\phi). Then the loss between ‚ÑíDsubscript‚Ñíùê∑{\mathscr{L}}_{D} and ‚ÑíUsubscript‚Ñíùëà{\mathscr{L}}_{U} is calculated. The quantity in Eq.¬†35 is the average of that loss.

Say that P(U(.,œï))P(U(.,\phi)) is the same function of U(.,œï)U(.,\phi) as P(Uc(.,œï))P(U_{c}(.,\phi)) is of Uc(.,œï)U_{c}(.,\phi). Then the Bayesian estimator is based on the actual prior. In this case, the Bayesian estimator ‚Ñí~Dsubscript~‚Ñíùê∑{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} will minimize the prior-averaged expected loss of Eq.¬†35.222222To see this, replace ‚Ñí~Dsubscript~‚Ñíùê∑{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} with some arbitrary function of Dùê∑D, f‚Äã(D)ùëìùê∑f(D). Our task it to solve for the optimal fùëìf. First interchange the integrals over data and over oracles in Eq.¬†35. Next consider the integrand of the outer (data) integral, ‚à´dU(.,œï)P(U(.,œï))‚àèi=1Nv(wi)L[f(D),‚à´dw‚Ä≤U(w‚Ä≤,œï)]].\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)\;P(U(.,\phi))\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})L[f(D),\;\int d{w}^{\prime}\;U({w}^{\prime},\phi)]]. Since we are considering a noise-free oracle, we can write this as ‚à´dU(.,œï)P(U(.,œï))P(D‚à£v,U(.,œï))L[f(D),‚ÑíU(œï)].\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)\;P(U(.,\phi))P(D\mid v,U(.,\phi))L[f(D),{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)]. Since P(U(.,œï))P(D‚à£v,U(.,œï))‚àùP(U(.,œï)‚à£v,D)=P(U(.,œï)‚à£D)P(U(.,\phi))P(D\mid v,U(.,\phi))\propto P(U(.,\phi)\mid v,D)=P(U(.,\phi)\mid D), this integral is minimized by setting f‚Äã(D)=‚Ñí~Dùëìùê∑subscript~‚Ñíùê∑f(D)={\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D}. QED. In general though, there is no reason to suppose that these two priors are the same. In the real world where those priors differ, expected loss for a Bayesian estimator is given by an inner product between the posterior used by that estimator, P(Uc(.,œï)‚à£D)P(U_{c}(.,\phi)\mid D), and the true posterior, P(U(.,œï)‚à£D)P(U(.,\phi)\mid D)¬†(see Wolpert, 1997, 1996).232323It is in recognition of the fact that those functions might differ that we have been referring to ‚ÄòBayesian‚Äô rather than ‚ÄòBayes-optimal‚Äô estimators.

As before, since U(.œï)U(.\phi) varies in the integrand of prior-averaged expected loss, we can can adapt it to get a prior-averaged expected risk. This is given by

‚à´dU(.,œï)P(U(.,œï))‚à´dw1‚Ä¶dwN‚àèi=1Nv(wi)√ó\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\int dU(.,\phi)\;P(U(.,\phi))\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})\;\;\times
{L‚Äã[‚Ñí~{(wi,U‚Äã(wi,œï))},‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)]‚àíminœÅ‚àà‚Ñù‚Äã[L‚Äã[œÅ,‚Ñí‚Äã(œï)]]}.ùêøsubscript~‚Ñísuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñitalic-œï‚Ñíitalic-œïsubscriptminùúå‚Ñùdelimited-[]ùêøùúå‚Ñíitalic-œï\displaystyle\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\{L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{({w}^{i},U({w}^{i},\phi))\}},\;{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)]\;\;-\;\;{\mbox{min}}_{\rho\in{\mathbb{R}}}[L[\rho,\;{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)]]\}. (36)

As before, if the minimal loss is always 0, then prior-averaged expected risk just equals prior-averaged expected loss.

Broadly speaking, in Bayesian approaches to Monte Carlo problems, the sampling distribution that generated the samples is immaterial once one those samples have been generated ¬†(see Rasmussen and Gharamani, 2003) and references therein). So what difference does the choice of a sampling distribution like vùë£v make to a Bayesian? The answer is that vùë£v determines how likely it is that we will generate a Dùê∑D with a high posterior variance of the quantity of interest. For example, say one wishes to form an importance sampling estimate of ‚Ñí=‚à´ùëëx‚ÄãU‚Äã(x)‚Ñídifferential-dùë•ùëàùë•{\mathscr{L}}=\int dx\;U(x) using sampling distribution vùë£v to generate sample set Dùê∑D. Then if one changes vùë£v, one changes the likelihoods of the possible Dùê∑D. Moreover, each Dùê∑D has its own posterior variance, Var(‚Ñíc‚à£D)conditionalsubscript‚Ñíùëêùê∑({\mathscr{L}}_{c}\mid D). So what a good choice of vùë£v means is that a Dùê∑D with poor Var(‚Ñíc‚à£D)conditionalsubscript‚Ñíùëêùê∑({\mathscr{L}}_{c}\mid D) is unlikely to be formed, that is, that ‚à´ùëëD‚ÄãP‚Äã(D‚à£v)‚ÄãVar‚Äã(‚Ñíc‚à£D)differential-dùê∑ùëÉconditionalùê∑ùë£Varconditionalsubscript‚Ñíùëêùê∑\int dD\;P(D\mid v){\mbox{Var}}({\mathscr{L}}_{c}\mid D) is low.

6.6 Statistical Analysis of FB MCO

We can extend the statistical analysis of FB MC to the case of FB MCO by allowing œïitalic-œï\phi to vary. The Bayesian choice of œïitalic-œï\phi is the one that minimizes posterior expected loss,

œï~Dsubscript~italic-œïùê∑\displaystyle{\tilde{\phi}}_{D} ‚âú‚âú\displaystyle\triangleq argminœï‚Äã[‚à´ùëëUc‚ÄãP‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)‚ÄãL‚Äã(œï,Uc)].subscriptargminitalic-œïdelimited-[]differential-dsubscriptùëàùëêùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑ùêøitalic-œïsubscriptùëàùëê\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{\phi}[\int dU_{c}\;P(U_{c}\mid D)L(\phi,U_{c})]. (37)

Since P‚Äã(Uc‚à£v,D)=P‚Äã(Uc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùë£ùê∑ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùëàùëêùê∑P(U_{c}\mid v,D)=P(U_{c}\mid D), this estimator is independent of vùë£v. The same is true for the posterior expected loss of this Bayesian estimator,

‚à´ùëëU‚ÄãP‚Äã(U‚à£D)‚ÄãL‚Äã(œï~D,U).differential-dùëàùëÉconditionalùëàùê∑ùêøsubscript~italic-œïùê∑ùëà\displaystyle\int dU\;P(U\mid D)L({\tilde{\phi}}_{D},U). (38)

On the other hand, the expected loss associated with this estimator,

‚à´ùëëw1‚Äã‚Ä¶‚ÄãùëëwN‚Äã‚àèi=1Nv‚Äã(wi)‚ÄãL‚Äã(œï~{wi,U‚Äã(wi)},U),differential-dsuperscriptùë§1‚Ä¶differential-dsuperscriptùë§ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÅùë£superscriptùë§ùëñùêøsubscript~italic-œïsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëà\displaystyle\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})L({\tilde{\phi}}_{\{{w}^{i},U({w}^{i})\}},U), (39)

explicitly depends on vùë£v. So does the prior-averaged expected loss,

‚à´ùëëU‚ÄãP‚Äã(U)‚Äã‚à´ùëëw1‚Äã‚Ä¶‚ÄãùëëwN‚Äã‚àèi=1Nv‚Äã(wi)‚ÄãL‚Äã(œï~{wi,U‚Äã(wi)},U).differential-dùëàùëÉùëàdifferential-dsuperscriptùë§1‚Ä¶differential-dsuperscriptùë§ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÅùë£superscriptùë§ùëñùêøsubscript~italic-œïsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëà\displaystyle\int dU\;P(U)\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})L({\tilde{\phi}}_{\{{w}^{i},U({w}^{i})\}},U). (40)

Next, the posterior expected risk is

‚à´ùëëU‚ÄãP‚Äã(U‚à£D)‚Äã{L‚Äã(œï~D,U)‚àíminœï‚Ä≤‚Äã[L‚Äã(œï‚Ä≤,U)]}differential-dùëàùëÉconditionalùëàùê∑ùêøsubscript~italic-œïùê∑ùëàsubscriptminsuperscriptitalic-œï‚Ä≤delimited-[]ùêøsuperscriptitalic-œï‚Ä≤ùëà\displaystyle\int dU\;P(U\mid D)\{L({\tilde{\phi}}_{D},U)\;\;-\;\;{\mbox{min}}_{\phi^{\prime}}[L(\phi^{\prime},U)]\} (41)

where œï‚Ä≤superscriptitalic-œï‚Ä≤\phi^{\prime} runs over the (implicit) set of all possible œïitalic-œï\phi. In general minœï‚Ä≤‚Äã[L‚Äã(œï‚Ä≤,U)]subscriptminsuperscriptitalic-œï‚Ä≤delimited-[]ùêøsuperscriptitalic-œï‚Ä≤ùëà{\mbox{min}}_{\phi^{\prime}}[L(\phi^{\prime},U)] varies with UùëàU. (For example, this is the case with the loss function ‚ÑíU‚Äã(œï)subscript‚Ñíùëàitalic-œï{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi) of Eq.¬†4.) Accordingly, unlike in Bayesian FB MC, typically in Bayesian FB MCO the posterior expected risk does not equal the posterior expected loss.

Finally, the prior-averaged expected risk is

‚à´ùëëU‚Äãùëëw1‚Äã‚Ä¶‚ÄãùëëwN‚ÄãP‚Äã(U)‚Äã‚àèi=1Nv‚Äã(wi)‚Äã{L‚Äã(œï~{wi,U‚Äã(wi)},U)‚àíminœï‚Ä≤‚Äã[L‚Äã(œï‚Ä≤,U)]}.differential-dùëàdifferential-dsuperscriptùë§1‚Ä¶differential-dsuperscriptùë§ùëÅùëÉùëàsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëÅùë£superscriptùë§ùëñùêøsubscript~italic-œïsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsuperscriptùë§ùëñùëàsubscriptminsuperscriptitalic-œï‚Ä≤delimited-[]ùêøsuperscriptitalic-œï‚Ä≤ùëà\displaystyle\int dUd{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\;P(U)\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})\{L({\tilde{\phi}}_{\{{w}^{i},U({w}^{i})\}},U)\;\;-\;\;{\mbox{min}}_{\phi^{\prime}}[L(\phi^{\prime},U)]\}. (42)

Again, since minœï‚Ä≤‚Äã[L‚Äã(œï‚Ä≤,U)]subscriptminsuperscriptitalic-œï‚Ä≤delimited-[]ùêøsuperscriptitalic-œï‚Ä≤ùëà{\mbox{min}}_{\phi^{\prime}}[L(\phi^{\prime},U)] typically varies with UùëàU, in general this prior-averaged expected risk does not equal the prior-averaged expected loss. However the estimator that minimizes prior-averaged expected loss ‚Äî œï~Dsubscript~italic-œïùê∑{\tilde{\phi}}_{D} ‚Äî is the same as the estimator that minimizes prior-averaged expected risk.242424This follows from the fact that the prior-averaged lowest possible risk, the term subtracted in Eq.¬†42, is independent of the choice of the estimator.

For any particular fitting algorithm, our equations tell us how performance of the associated FB MCO depends on vùë£v and either P(U(.,œï))P(U(.,\phi)) or the pair P(U(.,œï))P(U(.,\phi)) and P(Uc(.,œï))P(U_{c}(.,\phi)), depending on which equation we consider. So if we fix those prior(s), our equations tell us, formally, what the optimal vùë£v is.

One can consider estimating that optimal vùë£v at a mid-way point of the algorithm, based on the algorithm‚Äôs behavior up to that point. One can then set vùë£v to that estimate for the remainder of the algorithm.252525Note though that if one intends to update vùë£v more than once, then strictly speaking the first update to vùë£v should take into account the fact that the future update will occur. That means the equations above for expected loss, prior-averaged expected loss, etc., no longer apply. Doing this essentially amounts to a type of active learning.

As with Bayesian FBMC, we can analyze the effects of having P‚Äã(U)ùëÉùëàP(U) not be the same function of UùëàU as P‚Äã(Uc)ùëÉsubscriptùëàùëêP(U_{c}) is of UcsubscriptùëàùëêU_{c}. Since PL and MCO are formally the same, such an analysis applies to parametric machine learning in addition to FB MCO. In particular, the analysis gives a Bayesian correction to the bias-variance decomposition of supervised learning. This correction holds even if the fitting algorithm in the supervised learning cannot be cast as Bayes-optimal for some assumed prior P‚Äã(Uc)ùëÉsubscriptùëàùëêP(U_{c}). Intuitively speaking, the correction means that the bias-variance decomposition gets replaced by a bias-variance-covariance decomposition. That covariance is between the posterior distribution over target functions on the one hand, and the posterior distribution over fits produced by the fitting algorithm on the other¬†(see Wolpert, 1997).

6.7 Combining FB and Non-FB Estimates in FB MCO

Return now to the example in Sec.¬†6.6, where the factual sample is formed by importance sampling the factual oracle and we form a fictitious sample set using fictitious oracles.Then using only Dùê∑{D}, our estimate of ‚Ñ±G‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùê∫ùúÉ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(\theta) would be the factual estimate, ‚Ñ±^D‚Äã(Œ∏)=‚àëk=1Nrk‚Äã(Œ∏)Nsubscript^‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùëÅsuperscriptùëüùëòùúÉùëÅ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{{D}}(\theta)=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}r^{k}(\theta)}{N}. Using only our fictitious samples would instead give us the estimate ‚Ñ±~^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^~‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta).

On the one extreme, say we firmly believe that distribution we use for the posterior P‚Äã(Gc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùëêùê∑P({G_{c}}\mid D) is correct. (So in particular we firmly believe that the factual oracle Gùê∫G was generated by sampling the prior P‚Äã(Gc)ùëÉsubscriptùê∫ùëêP(G_{c}).) Then in the limit NT‚Üí‚àû‚ÜísubscriptùëÅùëáN_{T}\rightarrow\infty, ‚àÄŒ∏for-allùúÉ\forall\theta our importance-sample estimate of ‚Ñ±~Dsubscript~‚Ñ±ùê∑{\tilde{{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D} will be exactly correct. So Bayesian decision theory would direct us to use the associated estimate ‚Ñ±~^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^~‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta), and ignore ‚Ñ±^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{{D}}(\theta). At the other extreme, say that NT=1subscriptùëÅùëá1N_{T}=1, while NùëÅN, the number of factual samples, is quite large. In such a situation, even if we believe our posterior is correct, it would clearly be wrong to use ‚Ñ±~^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^~‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta) as our estimate, ignoring ‚Ñ±^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{{D}}(\theta).

How should we combine the estimates in this latter situation? More generally, even when we believe our posterior is correct, unless the number of fictitious samples is far greater than the number of factual samples, we should combine the two associated estimates. How best to do that? Does the fact that ‚Ñ±~^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^~‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta) is estimated via importance sampling over a much larger space than ‚Ñ±^D‚Äã(Œ∏)subscript^‚Ñ±ùê∑ùúÉ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{{D}}(\theta) affect how we should combine them? More generally, say we don‚Äôt presume that our P‚Äã(Gc‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùëêùê∑P({G_{c}}\mid{{D}}) is exactly correct; how should we combine the estimates then?

One is tempted to invoke Bayesian reasoning to determine how best to combine the two estimates. While that might be possible in certain situations, often determining the optimal Bayesian combination would necessitate yet more Monte Carlo sampling of some new integrals. It would be nice if some other approach could be used.

One potential such approach is stacking¬†(Wolpert, 1992; Breiman, 1996; Smyth and Wolpert, 1999). In this approach, one many times partitions the factual sample Dùê∑D into two parts, a ‚Äòtraining set‚Äô D1superscriptùê∑1D^{1}, and a ‚Äòvalidation set‚Äô D2superscriptùê∑2D^{2}. We write the values of wùë§w and UùëàU in D1superscriptùê∑1D^{1} as {Dw1‚Äã(i)}superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùë§1ùëñ\{D_{w}^{1}(i)\} and {DU1‚Äã(i,œï)}superscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëà1ùëñitalic-œï\{D_{U}^{1}(i,\phi)\} respectively, and similarly for D2superscriptùê∑2D^{2}. For each such partition one would run both the non-FB MCO algorithm and the FB MCO algorithm on D1superscriptùê∑1D^{1}. That generates the estimates œï^v,U,D1subscript^italic-œïùë£ùëàsuperscriptùê∑1{\hat{\phi}}_{v,U,D^{1}} and œï~^D1subscript^~italic-œïsuperscriptùê∑1{\hat{\tilde{\phi}}}_{D^{1}}, respectively.

Those two œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs give us two associated error values on the validation set, ‚àëjDU2‚Äã(j,œï^v,U,D1)subscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëà2ùëósubscript^italic-œïùë£ùëàsuperscriptùê∑1\sum_{j}D_{U}^{2}(j,{\hat{\phi}}_{v,U,D^{1}}) and ‚àëjDU2‚Äã(j,œï~^D1)subscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëà2ùëósubscript^~italic-œïsuperscriptùê∑1\sum_{j}D_{U}^{2}(j,{\hat{\tilde{\phi}}}_{D^{1}}), respectively. More generally, we can evaluate the error on the the validation set of a‚Äãn‚Äãyùëéùëõùë¶any œïitalic-œï\phi, in addition to the errors of œï^v,U,D1subscript^italic-œïùë£ùëàsuperscriptùê∑1{\hat{\phi}}_{v,U,D^{1}} and œï~^D1subscript^~italic-œïsuperscriptùê∑1{\hat{\tilde{\phi}}}_{D^{1}}. Moreover, we can do this for the validation set of any of the partitions of Dùê∑D. Note, however, that only factual samples are used for cross-validation.

This is what stacking exploits. In the most straightforward use of stacking, one searches for a function mapping the œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs produced by our two algorithms to a composite œïitalic-œï\phi. The goal is to find such a composite œïitalic-œï\phi that will have as small validation set error (when averaged over all partitions) as possible.

For example, if œïitalic-œï\phi is a Euclidean vector, one could perform a regularized search for the weighted sum of œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs that gives minimal partition-averaged validation set error. Let the weights produced by that search be bF‚ÄãBsubscriptùëèùêπùêµb_{FB} and bn‚Äão‚Äãn‚àíF‚ÄãBsubscriptùëèùëõùëúùëõùêπùêµb_{non-FB}. Then to find the final estimate for œïitalic-œï\phi, one would use those weights to sum the outputs of the algorithms when run on all of Dùê∑D: bn‚Äão‚Äãn‚àíF‚ÄãB‚Äãœï^v,U,D+bF‚ÄãB‚Äãœï~Dsubscriptùëèùëõùëúùëõùêπùêµsubscript^italic-œïùë£ùëàùê∑subscriptùëèùêπùêµsubscript~italic-œïùê∑b_{non-FB}{\hat{\phi}}_{v,U,D}\;+\;b_{FB}{\tilde{\phi}}_{D}.

7 Conclusion

In this paper we explored the relationship between Monte Carlo Optimization of a parametrized integral, parametric machine learning, and ‚Äòblackbox‚Äô or ‚Äòoracle‚Äô-based optimization. We made four contributions.

First, we proved that MCO is identical to a broad class of parametric machine learning problems. This should open a new application domain for previously investigated parametric machine learning techniques, to the problem of MCO.

To test the use of PL in MCO one needs an MCO problem domain. The one we used was based on our second contribution, which was the introduction of immediate sampling. Immediate sampling is a way to transform an arbitrary blackbox optimization problem into an MCO problem. Accordingly, it provides us a way to test the use of PL to improve MCO, but testing whether it can improve blackbox optimization.

In our third contribution we validated this way of improving blackbox optimization. In particular, we demonstratied that cross-validation and bagging improve immediate sampling.

Conventional Monte Carlo and MCO procedures ignore some features of the sample data. In particular, they ignore the relationship between the sample point locations and the associated values of the integrand; only the values of the integrand at those locations are considered. We ended by presenting fit-based MCO, which is a way to exploit the information in the sample locations.

There are many PL techniques that should be applicable to immediate sampling but that are not experimentally tested in this paper. These include density estimation active learning, stacking, kernel-based methods, boosting, etc. Current and future work involves experimental tests of the ability of such techniques to improve MCO in general and immediate sampling in particular.

Other future work is to conduct experimental investigations of the three techniques that we presented in this paper but did not test. One of these is fit-based MCO (and fit-based immediate sampling in particular). The other two are the techniques described in the appendices: immediate sampling for constrained optimization problems, and immediate sampling with elite objective functions.

There are also many potential application domains for immediate sampling PC for blackbox optimization that we intend to explore. Some of these exploit the ability of such PC to handle arbitrary (mixed) data types of xùë•x‚Äôs. In particular, one such data type is the full trajectory of a system through a space; for optimizing a problem over such a space, PC becomes a form of reinforcement learning.

Appendix A Constrained Optimization

Under the PC transform we replace an optimization problem over XùëãX with one over ùí¨ùí¨{\mathscr{Q}}. As discussed at the beginning of Sec.¬†3.3, the characteristics of the transformed objective can be very different from those of the original objective.

Similarly, characteristics of any constraints on XùëãX in the original problem can also change significantly under this transformation. More precisely, say we add to (P4) equality and inequality constraints restricting x‚ààXùë•ùëãx\in X to a feasible region. Then to satisfy those XùëãX-constraints we need to modify (P5) to ensure that the support of the solution qŒ∏(.)q_{\theta}(.) is a subset of the feasible region in XùëãX.

This appendix considers some ways of modifying PC to do this. For earlier work on this topic in the context of delayed sampling, see¬†Wolpert et¬†al. (2006); Bieniawski and Wolpert (2004); Bieniawski et¬†al. (2004); Macready and Wolpert (2005).

See the discussion at the end of Sec.¬†3.1 on product distributions and p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq distance. in Eq.¬†43.

To generate a sample of sample qŒ∏‚Äã(x)=q~Œ∏‚Äã(x)‚ÄãŒ¶‚Äã(x)subscriptùëûùúÉùë•subscript~ùëûùúÉùë•Œ¶ùë•q_{\theta}(x)={{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}}(x)\Phi(x) we can subsample272727Say we want to sample a distribution A‚Äã(x)‚àùB‚Äã(x)‚ÄãC‚Äã(x)proportional-toùê¥ùë•ùêµùë•ùê∂ùë•A(x)\propto B(x)C(x) where BùêµB is a distribution and Cùê∂C is non-negative definite, with cùëêc some upper bound on Cùê∂C. To generate such a sample by ‚Äòsubsampling BùêµB according to Cùê∂C‚Äô we first generate a random sample of B(.)B(.), getting x‚Ä≤superscriptùë•‚Ä≤x^{\prime}. We then toss a coin with bias C‚Äã(x‚Ä≤)/cùê∂superscriptùë•‚Ä≤ùëêC(x^{\prime})/c. If that coin comes up heads, we keep x‚Ä≤superscriptùë•‚Ä≤x^{\prime} as our sample of Aùê¥A. Otherwise we repeat the process¬†(see Wolpert et¬†al., 2006; Robert and Casella, 2004). q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta} according to Œ¶Œ¶\Phi. In some cases though, this can be very inefficient (that is, one may get many rejections before getting a feasible xùë•x). To deal with such cases, we can first run a density estimator on the samples of feasible xùë•x‚Äôs we have so far, getting a distribution œÄùúã\pi. (Note that no extra calls to the feasibility oracle are needed to do this.) Next write qŒ∏‚Äã(x)=œÄ‚Äã(x)‚Äã[qŒ∏‚Äã(x)/œÄ‚Äã(x)]subscriptùëûùúÉùë•ùúãùë•delimited-[]subscriptùëûùúÉùë•ùúãùë•q_{\theta}(x)=\pi(x)[q_{\theta}(x)/\pi(x)]. In an obvious modification to the foregoing, we can replace the hard restriction that supp(qùëûq) contain only feasible xùë•x‚Äôs, with a ‚Äòsoft‚Äô constraint that q‚Äã(x)‚â§Œ∫‚Äã‚àÄinfeasible‚Äãxùëûùë•ùúÖfor-allinfeasibleùë•q(x)\leq\kappa\;\forall\;{\mbox{infeasible}}\;x. A similar alternative is to ‚Äòsoften‚Äô Œ¶‚Äã(x)Œ¶ùë•\Phi(x) by replacing it with Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa for all infeasible xùë•x, for some Œ∫>0ùúÖ0\kappa>0. For either alternative we anneal Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa down to 0, as usual, perhaps using cross-validation.

A.2 Alternative ‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢{\mathscr{F}}_{{\mathscr{G}}}

Since we‚Äôre maximizing our expression over q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}}, the second, correcting integral in Eq.¬†43 will tend to push q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}} to have probability mass a‚Äãw‚Äãa‚Äãyùëéùë§ùëéùë¶away from feasible regions. To understand this intuitively, say that q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}} is a Gaussian and that the feasible region is ‚Äòspiky‚Äô, resembling a multi-dimensional star-fish with a large central region and long, thin legs. For this situation, if we over-concentrate on keeping most of q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}}‚Äôs mass restricted to feasible xùë•x, our Gaussian will be pushed away from any of the spikes of the feasible xùë•x‚Äôs, and concentrate on the center. If the solution to our original optimization problem is in one of those spikes, such over-concentration is a fatal flaw. The second integral in Eq.¬†43 corrects for this potential problem.

More broadly, consider typical case behavior when one applies some particular constrained optimization algorithm to any of the problems in a particular class of optimization problems. As a practical matter, there is a spectrum of such problem classes, indexed by how difficult it is just to find feasible solutions on typical problems of the class. On the one side of this spectrum are problem classes where it is exceedingly difficult to find such a solution, e.g., high-dimensional satisfiability problems with a performance measure Gùê∫G superimposed to compare potential solutions. On the other end are ‚Äúsimple‚Äù problem classes where it is reasonable to expect to find a feasible solution. The ‚Äòstarfish‚Äô optimization problem is an example of a problem of the former type.282828Note that since we are discussing typical-case behavior, computational complexity considerations do not apply.

For problems on the first side of the spectrum, where just getting a substantial amount of probability mass into the feasible region is very difficult, we may want to leave out the second integral in Eq.¬†43. In other words, we may want to minimize KL(pŒ¶Œ≤||q~Œ∏)(p^{\beta}_{\Phi}\;||\;{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}) rather than KL(pŒ¶Œ≤||q~Œ¶,Œ∏)(p^{\beta}_{\Phi}\;||\;{\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta}). The reason to make this change is so that q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta} won‚Äôt get pushed away from the feasible region. (As an aside, another potential benefit of this change is that if we make it, then for product distribution q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}, ‚Ñ±ùí¢(.){\mathscr{F}}_{{\mathscr{G}}}(.) is convex.)

Even if we do make this change, when we sample the resultant q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta} we may not get a feasible xùë•x. If this happens, a natural approach is to repeatedly sample q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta} until we do get a feasible xùë•x. However the resultant distribution of xùë•x‚Äôs is the same as that formed by sampling q~Œ¶,Œ∏subscript~ùëûŒ¶ùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta} for the same Œ∏ùúÉ\theta. So under this ‚Äônatural approach‚Äô we work to optimize a distribution (q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}) different from the one we ultimately sample (q~Œ¶,Œ∏subscript~ùëûŒ¶ùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta}). This means that this approach may not properly balance our two conflicting needs for q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}: that it have most of its support in the feasible region, and that it be peaked about xùë•x‚Äôs with high pŒ≤‚Äã(x)superscriptùëùùõΩùë•p^{\beta}(x).

To illustrate this issue differently, take q~Œ∏subscript~ùëûùúÉ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta} to be normalized, and to avoid multiplying and dividing by zero, modify Œ¶‚Äã(x)Œ¶ùë•\Phi(x) to equal some very small non-zero value Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa for infeasible xùë•x (as discussed above). Then under this ‚Äòcompound procedure‚Äô, we ultimately sample q~Œ¶,Œ∏(.){\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta}(.). However we do not choose ‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(q~Œ¶,Œ∏)=subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript~ùëûŒ¶ùúÉabsent{\mathscr{F}}_{{\mathscr{G}}}({\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta})= KL(pŒ¶Œ≤||q~Œ¶,Œ∏)(p^{\beta}_{\Phi}\;||\;{\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta}) as the function of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta that we want to minimize. Instead we choose

‚Ñ±ùí¢‚Äã(q~Œ¶,Œ∏)subscript‚Ñ±ùí¢subscript~ùëûŒ¶ùúÉ\displaystyle{\mathscr{F}}_{{\mathscr{G}}}({\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta}) =\displaystyle= KL(pŒ¶Œ≤||q~Œ¶,Œ∏)‚àíln[‚à´dx‚Ä≤q~Œ¶,Œ∏‚Äã(x‚Ä≤)Œ¶‚Äã(x‚Ä≤)].\displaystyle{\mbox{KL}}(p^{\beta}_{\Phi}\;||\;{\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta})\;-\;{\mbox{ln}}[\int dx^{\prime}\;\frac{{\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta}(x^{\prime})}{\Phi(x^{\prime})}]. (44)

A.3 Using Constraints for Unconstrained Optimization

Return now to unconstrained optimization problems. Say that we have reason to expect that over a particular region RùëÖR, the distribution pŒ≤‚Äã(x)superscriptùëùùõΩùë•p^{\beta}(x) has values approximately Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa times as small as its value over X‚àñRùëãùëÖX\setminus R. It would be nice to reflect this insight in our parametrization of qùëûq, that is, to parametrize qùëûq in a way that makes it easy to match it to pŒ≤‚Äã(x)superscriptùëùùõΩùë•p^{\beta}(x) accurately. We can do this using a binary-valued function Œ¶Œ¶\Phi and the approaches presented above.

This is because our goal now is simply to find a qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} that matches pŒ≤‚Äã(x)superscriptùëùùõΩùë•p^{\beta}(x). We could do that for example by using a regression to form a fit to samples of pŒ≤‚Äã(x)superscriptùëùùõΩùë•p^{\beta}(x) and then use that regression to define the region RùëÖR.

Appendix B The Elite Objective Function

Not all PC objectives can be cast as an integral transform. Properly speaking, the choice of objective should be set by how the final qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} will be used. For instance, the concept of expected improvement suggested by ¬†Mockus et¬†al. (1978), and used by Jones et¬†al. (1998), considers an objective (to be maximized) given by max‚Å°(Gbc‚àíG‚Äã(x),0)subscriptùê∫bcùê∫ùë•0\max(G_{\mathrm{bc}}-G(x),0), where Gbcsubscriptùê∫bcG_{\mathrm{bc}} is the best of all the current samples, mini‚Å°{G‚Äã(xi)}subscriptùëñùê∫superscriptùë•ùëñ\min_{i}\{G(x^{i})\}. This means that at each step we will take a single sample, and want to maximize the improvement. This is a simplification; even though the next sample may yield any improvement, it may be informative, so that we get a good sample ten steps later. A less simplistic objective is the following:

In blackbox optimization, no matter how many calls to the (factual) oracle we make, we will ultimately choose the best xùë•x (as far as the associated Gùê∫G value is concerned) out of all the ones that were fed to the oracle during the course of the entire run. Our true goal in BO is to have the Gùê∫G associated with t‚Äãh‚Äãa‚Äãtùë°‚Ñéùëéùë°that best xùë•x be as small as possible. For a discussion of distributions of extremal values, see ¬†Leadbetter et¬†al. (1983); Resnick (1987).

Given that qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} varies over the run in a way that we do not know beforehand, how can one approximate this goal as minimizing an objective function that is well-defined at all points during the run? One way to do this is to assume that there is some integer NùëÅN such that, simultaneously,

  1. 1.

    It is likely that the best xùë•x will be one of the final NùëÅN calls to the oracle during the run;

  2. 2.

    It is likely that qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} will not vary much during the generation of those final NùëÅN samples.

Under (2) we can approximate the qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}‚Äôs that are used to generate the final NùëÅN calls as all being equal to some canonical qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}. Under (1), our goal then becomes finding the canonical qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} that, when sampled NùëÅN times, produces a set of xùë•x‚Äôs whose best element is as good as possible. 313131An obvious variant of this reasoning is to have NùëÅN vary across the run of the entire algorithm, at any iteration tùë°t being only the number of remaining calls to the oracle that we presume will be made. In this variant, one would modify the elite objective function to only involve the N‚Äã(t)ùëÅùë°N(t) remaining samples whose Gùê∫G value is better than the best found by iteration tùë°t. For the case N=1ùëÅ1N=1, this is analogous to the expected improvement idea in¬†Jones et¬†al. (1998). Note that this variant objective function will change during the run, which may cause stability problems.

In this appendix we make some cursory comments about this objective function, which we call the elite objective function. We focus on the use of Bayesian FB techniques with this objective. For a noise-free oracle the CDF for the elite objective is

In particular there would be no need for regularization ‚Äî an analogous role is played by the prior P‚Äã(G)ùëÉùê∫P(G) underlying P‚Äã(G‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalùê∫ùê∑P(G\mid D).

When we cannot evaluate the integral in closed form we must approximate it. To illustrate this, as in Sec.¬†6, for simplicity consider a single-valued oracle Gùê∫G. This reduces Eq.¬†48 to

(49)

(The analogous FB MCO equation for objective functions involving a single integral Eq.¬†20; here the single ‚Äòxùë•x‚Äô in that equation is replaced with a set of KùêæK xùë•x‚Äôs sampled from qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}.) At the same time we draw NTsubscriptùëÅùëáN_{T} fictitious oracles from some sampling distribution HùêªH over oracles.

To simplify notation, let x‚Üí‚Üíùë•{\vec{x}} indicate such a KùêæK-tuple of xùë•x‚Äôs. (So for multidimensional XùëãX, x‚Üí‚Üíùë•{\vec{x}} is actually a matrix.) Also write

qŒ∏‚Äã(x‚Üí)subscriptùëûùúÉ‚Üíùë•\displaystyle q_{\theta}({\vec{x}}) ‚âú‚âú\displaystyle\triangleq ‚àèi=1KqŒ∏‚Äã(xk),superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùêæsubscriptùëûùúÉsuperscriptùë•ùëò\displaystyle\prod_{i=1}^{K}q_{\theta}(x^{k}),
G‚Äã(x‚Üí)ùê∫‚Üíùë•\displaystyle G({\vec{x}}) ‚âú‚âú\displaystyle\triangleq (G‚Äã(x1),‚Ä¶,G‚Äã(xK)).ùê∫superscriptùë•1‚Ä¶ùê∫superscriptùë•ùêæ\displaystyle(G(x^{1}),\ldots,G(x^{K})). (50)

With this notation, the estimate based on fictitious samples introduced in Sec.¬†6 becomes323232In practice there might be more efficient sampling procedures than Eq.¬†51. For example, one could form N‚ÄãKùëÅùêæNK samples of hc‚Äã(x)subscript‚Ñéùëêùë•{h_{c}}(x) and NùëÅN samples of H‚Äã(G)ùêªùê∫H(G), to get two sets, which one then subsamples many times, to get pairs [x‚Üí,G‚Äã(x‚Üí)]‚Üíùë•ùê∫‚Üíùë•[{\vec{x}},G({\vec{x}})].

‚àëi=1N‚àèj=iKqŒ∏‚Äã(xij)hc‚Äã(xij)‚ÄãP‚Äã(Gi‚à£D)H‚Äã(Gi)‚Äãmink=1,‚Ä¶‚ÄãK‚Äã{Gi‚Äã(xik)}.superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptproductùëóùëñùêæsubscriptùëûùúÉsubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëóùëñsubscript‚Ñéùëêsubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëóùëñùëÉconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùëñùê∑ùêªsubscriptùê∫ùëñsubscriptminùëò1‚Ä¶ùêæsubscriptùê∫ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëòùëñ\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{N}\prod_{j=i}^{K}\frac{q_{\theta}(x^{j}_{i})}{{h_{c}}(x^{j}_{i})}\frac{P(G_{i}\mid D)}{H(G_{i})}{\mbox{min}}_{k=1,\ldots K}\{G_{i}(x^{k}_{i})\}. (51)

As discussed in Sec.¬†6, it is often good to set H‚Äã(G)ùêªùê∫H(G) to be as close to P‚Äã(G‚à£D)ùëÉconditionalùê∫ùê∑P(G\mid D) as possible. So for example if we assume a Gaussian process model, typically we can set H‚Äã(Gi)=P‚Äã(Gi‚à£D)ùêªsubscriptùê∫ùëñùëÉconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùëñùê∑H(G_{i})=P(G_{i}\mid D), and then directly sample HùêªH to get the values of one Gisubscriptùê∫ùëñG_{i} at the KùêæK separate points xijsubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëóùëñx^{j}_{i}. Alternatively, we can first form a fit œï‚Äã(x)italic-œïùë•\phi(x) to the data in Dùê∑D. Next, for each of NùëÅN samples x‚Üíisubscript‚Üíùë•ùëñ{\vec{x}}_{i}, sample a colored (correlated) noise process over the KùêæK points {x‚Üíisubscript‚Üíùë•ùëñ{\vec{x}}_{i}} to get KùêæK real numbers. Finally, add those KùêæK numbers to the corresponding values {œï‚Äã(x‚Üíij):j=1,‚Ä¶,K}conditional-setitalic-œïsuperscriptsubscript‚Üíùë•ùëñùëóùëó1‚Ä¶ùêæ\{\phi({\vec{x}}_{i}^{j}):j=1,\ldots,K\}. This gives our desired sample of {Gi‚Äã(x‚Üíi)subscriptùê∫ùëñsubscript‚Üíùë•ùëñG_{i}({\vec{x}}_{i})}.

To illustrate the foregoing, suppose K=1ùêæ1K=1, and that we have no regularization on qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta}. Then, in general, the sum in Eq.¬†51 is minimized by a qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} that is a delta function about that data point xi1subscriptsuperscriptùë•1ùëñx^{1}_{i} with the best associated value Gi‚Äã(xi1)/hc‚Äã(xi1)subscriptùê∫ùëñsubscriptsuperscriptùë•1ùëñsubscript‚Ñéùëêsubscriptsuperscriptùë•1ùëñG_{i}(x^{1}_{i})/{h_{c}}(x^{1}_{i}). However for K>1ùêæ1K>1, even without regularization, the optimal qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} is not a delta function, in general.333333This suboptimality of a delta function qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} is similar to the suboptimality of having all KùêæK pulls in a multi-armed bandit problem be pulls of the same arm. In addition to the regularization-based argument in the text, this gives a more formal reason why the optimal qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} should not be infinitely peaked.

When K>1ùêæ1K>1, the peakedness of qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} parallels the peakedness of another non-negative function over xùë•x‚Äôs, namely P(G:G(x)¬†is minimized at¬†x‚à£D)P(G:G(x){\mbox{ is minimized at }}x\mid D). However, if we run a few iterations of FB MCO with the elite objective, then Dùê∑D grows, and so P(G:G(x)¬†is minimized at¬†x‚à£D)P(G:G(x){\mbox{ is minimized at }}x\mid D) gets increasingly peaked over xùë•x‚Äôs. (Intuitively, the larger Dùê∑D is, the more confident we are about Gùê∫G, and consequently the more confident we are about what regions of xùë•x‚Äôs minimize Gùê∫G.) Accordingly, qŒ∏subscriptùëûùúÉq_{\theta} gets increasingly peaked as the algorithm progresses.

Note that this happens even though there is no external annealing schedule. This reflects the fact that the elite objective has no hyperparameter or regularization parameter like the Œ≤ùõΩ\beta that appears in both the p‚Äãqùëùùëûpq and q‚Äãpùëûùëùqp objective functions.

Appendix C Gaussian Example for Risk Analysis

The following example illustrates the foregoing for the case of Gaussian œÄùúã\pi, where only moments of œÄùúã\pi up to order 2 matter.

To illustrate the foregoing, consider the simple case where there are only two œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs, œï1superscriptitalic-œï1\phi^{1} and œï2superscriptitalic-œï2\phi^{2}. Suppose that UùëàU and XùëãX are such that œÄùúã\pi is a two-dimensional Gaussian. Write œÄùúã\pi‚Äôs mean as Œºùúá\mu. Say that one of œÄùúã\pi‚Äôs principal axes is parallel to the diagonal line, l1=l2subscriptùëô1subscriptùëô2l_{1}=l_{2} (that is, one of the eigenvectors of œÄùúã\pi‚Äôs covariance matrix is parallel to the diagonal, and one is orthogonal to the diagonal). Write the standard deviation of œÄùúã\pi along that diagonal axis as œÉAsubscriptùúéùê¥\sigma_{A}, and write the standard deviation along the other, orthogonal axis as œÉBsubscriptùúéùêµ\sigma_{B}.

Since œÄùúã\pi‚Äôs covariance matrix has identical diagonal entries, and since the trace of that matrix is preserved under rotations, those entries are both 12‚Äã[œÉA2+œÉB2]12delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùúéùê¥2superscriptsubscriptùúéùêµ2\frac{1}{2}[\sigma_{A}^{2}+\sigma_{B}^{2}]. Since the determinant is preserved, and since œÉAsubscriptùúéùê¥\sigma_{A} is the variance parallel to the diagonal, this in turn means that œÄùúã\pi‚Äôs (identical) off-diagonal entries are 12‚Äã[œÉA2‚àíœÉB2]12delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùúéùê¥2superscriptsubscriptùúéùêµ2\frac{1}{2}[\sigma_{A}^{2}-\sigma_{B}^{2}]. The probability that MCO will choose œï1superscriptitalic-œï1\phi^{1} is the integral of œÄùúã\pi over the half-plane where œï1‚â§œï2superscriptitalic-œï1superscriptitalic-œï2\phi^{1}\leq\phi^{2}:

Pr‚Äã(‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï2)>‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï1))Pr^‚Ñísuperscriptitalic-œï2^‚Ñísuperscriptitalic-œï1\displaystyle{\mbox{Pr}}({{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}}(\phi^{2})>{{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}}(\phi^{1})) =\displaystyle= erf‚Å°(Œº2‚àíŒº1œÉB‚Äã2).erfsubscriptùúá2subscriptùúá1subscriptùúéùêµ2\displaystyle\operatorname{erf}(\frac{\mu_{2}-\mu_{1}}{\sigma_{B}\sqrt{2}}). (52)

Next, define

=\displaystyle= [Œº1‚àíŒº2]‚àíŒî‚ÄãL.delimited-[]subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2Œîùêø\displaystyle[\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}]-\Delta L.

So the difference in the value of the loss function between the two œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs is Œî‚ÄãLŒîùêø\Delta L, and the the difference in the biases of the two estimators ‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï1)^‚Ñísuperscriptitalic-œï1{{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}}(\phi^{1}) and ‚Ñí^‚Äã(œï2)^‚Ñísuperscriptitalic-œï2{{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}}(\phi^{2}) is Œî‚ÄãbŒîùëè\Delta b. Var‚Äã[‚Ñí‚Äã(œï1)]=Var‚Äã[‚Ñí‚Äã(œï2)]=œÉA2+œÉB22.Vardelimited-[]‚Ñísuperscriptitalic-œï1Vardelimited-[]‚Ñísuperscriptitalic-œï2superscriptsubscriptùúéùê¥2superscriptsubscriptùúéùêµ22\displaystyle{\mbox{Var}}[{\mathscr{L}}(\phi^{1})]\;\;=\;\;{\mbox{Var}}[{\mathscr{L}}(\phi^{2})]\;\;=\;\;\frac{\sigma_{A}^{2}+\sigma_{B}^{2}}{2}. So if we shrink the variance of either of the estimators, then we shrink an upper bound on œÉBsubscriptùúéùêµ\sigma_{B}.

For this case of a fixed set of œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs, it is illuminating to consider the difference between expected loss under a particular MCO algorithm and minimal expected loss over all œïitalic-œï\phi‚Äôs, that is, the risk of the MCO algorithm. Assuming Œî‚ÄãL<0Œîùêø0\Delta L<0, it is given by

=\displaystyle=
[erf‚Å°(Œº2‚àíŒº1œÉB‚Äã2)‚àíŒò‚Äã(Œî‚Äãb+Œº2‚àíŒº1)]√ó[Œº1‚àíŒº2‚àíŒî‚Äãb].delimited-[]erfsubscriptùúá2subscriptùúá1subscriptùúéùêµ2ŒòŒîùëèsubscriptùúá2subscriptùúá1delimited-[]subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2Œîùëè\displaystyle[\operatorname{erf}(\frac{\mu_{2}-\mu_{1}}{\sigma_{B}\sqrt{2}})-\Theta(\Delta b+\mu_{2}-\mu_{1})]\;\times\;[\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}-\Delta b]. (55)

Say that Œî‚Äãb=0Œîùëè0\Delta b=0. Then Eq.¬†55 shows that so long as Œº1‚â†Œº2subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2\mu_{1}\neq\mu_{2}, as œÉB‚Üí0‚Üísubscriptùúéùêµ0\sigma_{B}\rightarrow 0 risk goes to its minimal possible value of zero. So everything else being equal, shrinking the variance of either estimator reduces risk, essentially minimizing it. Alternatively, if we leave the variances of the two estimators unchanged, but increase their covariance, 12‚Äã[œÉA2‚àíœÉB2]12delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptùúé2ùê¥superscriptsubscriptùúéùêµ2\frac{1}{2}[\sigma^{2}_{A}-\sigma_{B}^{2}], then œÉAsubscriptùúéùê¥\sigma_{A} will increase, while œÉBsubscriptùúéùêµ\sigma_{B} must shrink. So again, the risk will get reduced. For the more general, non-Gaussian case, the high order moments may also come into play.
